posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Mazin says the info sounds about right, but he remembers that the original concept name was "Ridicule Root": https://twitter.com/Mazin__/status/1618163967633010691
So if both are true, I think what happened is this:
>level names were conceived to be food puns ala Kirby's Adventure
>R2 just so happens to use an alliterative name
>some dev pointed that out and the team like it enough to rename the other levels
>Ridicule Root was renamed to Dangerous Depths after the food theming was removed
I'm not sure where Crazy Toy Box fits in, though. There could've been a third set of level names at some point that were neither food-related nor alliteration. It also seems like R2 was either removed or unimplemented by the time of the Ver0.02 proto with Salad Plain, so DD had to be VERY shortlived compared to RR: https://forums.sonicretro.org/index.php?threads/sonic-cds-mysterious-cut-r2-level-discussion-post-origins-edition.41136/page-11#post-1032578
Either way, I'm glad we don't have to call it "R2" anymore, because that also refers to Desert Dazzle, the R2 replacement Taxman conceived of that eventually became Mania's Mirage Saloon. I motion for Ridicule Root because it seems the level was probably known by that name longer and the abbreviation is less confused with Desert Dazzle. What I want to know ultimately is: in what way was this level apparently worse than Wacky Workbench?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9590467
Tiger-Heli is probably the best beginner shmup there is as it forces you to learn all of the basics to complete it without dying, and also has very forgiving checkpoints. Ideally, you want to practice sections without dying though, as you can just brute-force through sections with dying.

It's just a very basic game that beginners would probably find too primitive/boring, and the main flaw is just that the terrain and enemies are so limited that it's hard to actually know/memorize which section you're at because it all flows together.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9590227
All depend on what you are looking for.

Any shmup can be your first it really, depend on the dedication you want to poor on it, even more true when nowdays you have training tools, adjustable auto fire,rewind and save states which make the training way more efficient and short.

Also be aware that some games can be average to hard to 1CC but very hard to insane 2ALL ( 2nd Loop), some Psikyo games are like this for example.

Now for the recommendation I try to give you some easily emulated or game available on steam or ACA :
Relatively easy.
Dariusburst AC : depend on the route but it mostly easy/mild hard at best for an 1CC)
Akai Katana got released last month it's a mild difficulty cave with a lot of thing to learn from.
Area 88 is fun arcade game you may learn movement and placement, learning curve is kind of flat but expect a small pick at level 5. give the snes/sfc version a try too.

Normal
R-type leo is kind of the same you may also learn some stuff about force and option (harder at level 4).
Fighting Hawk is close to Area 88 but as a verti. not too hard not too easy
Metal Black is between the 2 but you won't learn that much from as the game is weird AF.
some others weird shmup ; fun but wont learn much from them.
Xexex mild 1CC on the japanese version. (2all is another story)
X-Multiply is slightly harder to 1CC but at least you won't have a burnout dealing with it 2ALL even if it's hard.

Mild hard
Game Tengoku is cute nice and fun and you will learn tons of shit and tricks, but 2ALL is on another story, way too hard for it own good.
Dragon Spirit is old but it one of my favorite games ever, it come from a time where you needed a separate button to shoot sol enemies. Maybe a little bit long and learning curve can be a bitch.
Outzone depend on the version and weapon management can be a nice game to pick.

Also most Psikyo and Cave games 1CC can be put here.

posts.com:
Back in the 90s everyone agreed that Sonic was cool. Even if you weren't a fan of the games it was impossible to deny that he was a cool character. There's a few reasons for that.

>Sonic is literally black
Sonic was visually inspired by Michael Jackson, that's where the shoes come from. And he was voiced by Jaleel White, who is actually black contrary to his name. And hedgehogs are native to Africa. And this was a huge strength because it was during the 1990s when America was a post-racial society and many of the popular shows on TV were about black families like The Cosby Show, Fresh Prince and Family Matters. Everyone loved MJ and he even did the music for Sonic 3. There were also cool black rappers like MC Hammer who was famous for his Big Butt Song.
>Knuckles is black
Knuckles has dreadlocks and rap music plays during his levels in SA2. He's also very aggressive and has explosive anger. He's also quick to start throwing out punches.
>Tails is the token white friend
This is also why he's good with tech.
>Rouge is the sexy Latina with a big butt and large breasts
It's also why she dates Knuckles who is black.
>Amy is a trendy Japanese girl
Gotta have an Asian character to check off diversity points. In CD she was a little girl but in SA1 she came back all grown up and sexy and she really leaned into that bubblegum pop style that was popular at the time, this is evidenced by the short pink hair.

Sadly racial tensions have continued to rise in America over the years and in the 2000s it became cool to start hating on Sonic around the same time that it was cool to be racist again. And now today racial tensions are at an all time high after incidents like the BLM riots, and coincidentally Sonic gets more hate than ever. Being a Sonic fan will cause you to get hated on no differently than if you were a fat white chick who only dates black guys. Honestly it's a real shame because Sonic is still cool.

OP, you see in this sprite exactly what everyone sees. Everything else you add to it is basically making shit up. You can either do it worse or better. You're asking for some CSI shit when they zoom in into a screw on a car and see a reflection of a guy so they zoom in some more into his sunglasses and see a reflection of a car 100 miles away so they zoom in again and see the face of a killer.

>>9583547
NTA, but.
Point-and-click game with copious CGI, impressive production values, batshit insane plot, full voice acting, and it impressed Nintendo so much they hired a lot of the staff for their EAD team. It's Japan-only, for the moment being. Only times it got talked about before was when collector hoarders accidentally leaked a private mega folder with tons of games including this previously lost game.
Company did 3 games like these and folded shortly after. Supposedly uses a Macromedia type thing.

Some copyright troll trademarked a bunch of stuff including the logo for the game and took down most of the media about it online, and it looks more like erasing the game from existence than a prospective new release. Nearly nothing is left online.

The game is about a 5 year old American girl identifying as a bear (and portrayed as such) going to dangerous locations after hearing voices in her head. The game opens with her being refused a bus ride, that bus is bombed by terrorists and everyone is dead, the terrorists are gunned by an airplane and everyone is dead, and the girl inspects the bus and goes "It can't be helped". Then she has to avoid dying by starvation, getting hugged to death by a pedophile cop, getting killed in the crossfire of other terrorists in a public park where a schizophrenic woman thinks the heroine is daughter, and then an alien locale that defies description. I'm saddened the walkthrough was taken offline. I really want to see how this goes now that I learned more Japanese. The backstory intro roll itself (which is in English) alone is a riot.

>>9596951
>>9596953
Anon who posted that. It's still the original files, but they are preinstalled on an emulated Windows 98 Machine so the game is easy to play

The ISO file is in a folder titled 'Files' along with the Windows 98 drive, and is mounted to the machine so the game can run, but is also there to make it easier to use and explore compared to the format of the original files

To run the machine, run "Launch.bat" in the folder

>qemu-system-i386 -nodefaults -rtc base=localtime -display sdl -L pc-bios -m 256 -machine pc,hpet=off,usb=off,kernel-irqchip=off -device VGA -device lsi -device sb16 -drive file=Files/w98.qcw -cdrom Files/CB1_DISC.iso -boot c

Its just a one line command that launches the machine with the correct settings, but I obviously get not wanting to run some random batch script and exe, so you can also move the files to your own qemu install and it'll work fine

>>9600572
Not much, but there are two things you can try that may help.

First is to change '256' to '512' to increase the amount of memory the machine has, though I don't know if this will really help.

The other, if you are on Windows and have the Windows Hypervisor Platform enabled, is to change this
>-machine pc,hpet=off,usb=off,kernel-irqchip=off
to this
>-machine pc,accel=whpx,hpet=off,usb=off,kernel-irqchip=off
which will improve the general performance through virtualization

This can cause some issues related to shutting down the emulated machine though, but its nothing major

>most playthroughs spend more time moving thru magmoor than progressing in new areas
They really don't, Magmoor is a very direct area with little to stop your progress. Magmoor has extra elevators specifically to speed up backtracking like the one after Thardus and the one in Tallon Overworld.
>artifact hunt is only made more efficient by having done it in an earlier playthrough
You can get the hints to find all the artifacts when you get the Space Jump, early in the game. You don't have to go out of the way at all, it's right where you're already going.
>by knowing there's like 3 artifacts you can get early out of 14.
More like 6 out of 12. These are the artifacts you can get early without even leaving the critical path.
>Chozo (collect while getting x ray visor)
>Wild (collect on way to ice beam)
>Nature (collect on first visit to magmoor, many opportunities to collect later)
>Strength (collect while backtracking for space jump)
>Warrior (collect while backtracking for x ray visor)
>Truth (literally waiting for you in the temple)

I had to shrink Temporal Tantrum MAP24 slightly to avoid breaking the coordinate distance limit. I think one of the Sunder maps also had to be shrunk during the testing process for the same reason.

Basically, if two points on your map are too far apart, it causes overflows in some calculations, causing hit detection errors like melee either missing up close or hitting from ages away, and archviles having infinite range.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Updated rules for A Serious Case of /vr/:
>Map must be made for Serious Sam The Second Encounter 1.07 version (this is the most up to date retail version you get from Steam/GOG)
>Usage of custom textures, sounds, and music is approved and encourged
>Usage of custom entities or other mods is NOT allowed. Outside of textures, sounds, and music your map should be 100% vanilla with 1.07
>Please provide a readme listing your name (even if it's anonymous), map name, and sources for any custom content used
>Map must be beatable (duh) and have proper co-op support
>Do not make edits of existing maps
>Project host has the final say and can deny your entry if it is not up to /vr/ """standards""" (please put some effort into your map)

Tips:
>Trigger a checkpoint whenever a new weapon is picked up to ensure everyone spawns with an "up-to-date" arsenal
>Make co-op portals for arenas that get closed off (and one-way doors for any closed off rooms/secrets so players don't get trapped)
>Aim to balance your map around Serious difficulty first, but don't be afraid to make support for other difficulties afterwards
>Also keep co-op in mind when balancing encounters, drawn out reinforcement spawners are not fun to wait on
>Hot Starts are not that common in Serious Sam, try making a "lobby" room for players to jump around in without risk of triggering anything (useful for co-op)
>A good fight is more enjoyable than a good looking room, don't stress yourself out over brushwork
>Use the official maps as references (I won't berate you for coping models, texture work, etc. from official maps) (You can have multiple maps opened at once and switch between them in the editor)
>Don't forget to make a thumbnail for your level
>Get creative with secrets!

Any other comments or suggestions? I will officially start this next weekend but anyone who's interested can start now if they want.

A level that "necessitate" saves is probably not very good. Or just plain trial-and-error.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9592276
>>9592278
You don't need a FX2 chip. All the FX2 did was support larger ROMs than the FX1, the FX1 otherwise performs the same as the FX2. Many people assumed the FX1 runs slower from trying to use Star Fox 1 as the doner cart, but the chip used in Star Fox 1 was slower variant called the Mario Chip. The ROM of Star Fox 2 is small enough to be fully addressable with the FX1. The most likely reason that Star Fox 2 was going to use a FX2 chip is that they were probably not producing the FX1 anymore, not that it needed it. Even if the FX2 cost more to make, having production of both FX1 and FX2 going on at the same time when any FX1 game would run the same on a FX2 would have cost more.

There are far less games that had a FX2 in them, and even less that had battery SRAM. About your only option outside of Tealand is Doom and Yoshi's Island, both rare and expensive.

Meanwhile the Dirt Trax FX and Stunt Race FX games can be had for $10-15 at times and there were tons of those. Yeah, it does suck to have to cannabalize older SNES games to make one of these, but there is no real way to create your own from scratch due to it being an FX game. No homebrew way to create your own FX chip. I mean, it can probably be implemented with a FPGA but I have zero clue how powerful (and thus expensive) an FPGA one would need. I tried to lookup the hardware in the FXPak but all I could find was that a prototype from 2011 used a Spartan 3 FPGA, no idea if the current carts also use that. Depending on the version they go from $18 to $120, most seem to be $18-40.

As for making it, many have made such a repro in the past. Most of them back then were made with the beta ROM that was floating around for years before the SNES Classic. Issue is with this having been done years ago, most guides are listing parts that are no longer easy to get (mostly the EEPROM) but if you know what you are doing you can use just about any viable EEPROM that's big enough and has the necessary pins.

>I understand a game being hard, but if it's caused by fake difficulty like equipment, spells, stats or classes not working, then it's just sad how aggressively some people defend it.

What's sad is how aggressively people SUPPORT the claim that any of these games is hard. FF1 is easy. It's a JRPG, so it's easy. Also, it's a JRPG so its biggest problems by far are those inherent in the definition of the genre. The bugs are a problem, but they're tiny in comparison to the basic flaws of the genre. Don't worry about the bugs. Play a version with them fixed or play an original version, and you'll have about the same experience. People can't shut up about them because only nerds care about old games like these and nerds can't stop their stupid brains from fixating on objectively quantifiable technical details, or from driving them to tell everybody else over and over about the special non-obvious knowledge they know so they can feel as if they've solved the problem of others' ignorance. Ignore that kind of nerd and forget about the stupid FF1 bugs. The only "difficulty" in these games is that they may require of you much patience. You have to trade time for progress, regardless of your skill level; that's part of the genre. You like it, or you don't, or you're somewhere in between. It's up to you. Don't worry about other factors because that's the only thing that might get in your way. And don't think new JRPGs or remakes of old ones are any different in this regard. "Time for progress" is just part of the genre.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9570560
>My question is, why shouldn't I play the original NES? Is it really that bad? And which even are the original ones?
The programmer Nasir, was unfamiliar with RPGs and barely managed to code the game together. The classic Final Fantasies were always a little buggy, but typically you'd have to really go out of your way to notice - the first Final Fantasy is obviously roughest since it was Nasir's first attempt. Elemental weapons don't work as they should, a good fourth or third of the spells weren't playtested, stat bugs, etc. The game got more or less fully bugfixed in the WonderSwan Color remake and its PlayStation port. Rereleases from GBA onward go further and are based on the latter's easy mode, changing up a lot of the game mechanics to make it even easier. They don't really represent the original experience too well.
As far as the second game goes, reception is generally the opposite. A lot of people didn't care in retrospect about the experimental gameplay, so you see more people vouching for GBA-onward rereleases of II. GBA also adds a postgame, but like almost all the rerelease-padded content, it's not very good, in this case being a remix of the final dungeons. You might want to try GBA or PR if original just doesn't click with you.
Beyond that, III is more enjoyable in either 2D form for myriad reasons, and nearly any version of IV is decent (except WSC/GBA, & 3D TAY is horrible). The rest should be played in original form where possible, give or take a translation/restoration patch.
>I mostly care about translation accuracy
The ChaosRush one is the one you want then, preferably with an enhancement that makes the game play more like rereleases / as intended. Default is probably better since Chaos Edition looks like it makes a bit too much guesswork with DND equivalents. If you play a rerelease, note the script has been somewhat expanded in WSC and again on GBA to account for increased text space. WSC fantranslations are incomplete unfortunately.

People obsess over the little bugs in FF1 but in truth, bugs in 8-bit RPGs are the norm. Probably a combination of having less experience from what came before, less playstesting, and limited RAM and ROM. FF1, FF2, DQ2, DQ3, Metal Max, Mother, Pokémon, etc etc they all have their share of bugs and the funny thing is, very often you'll stumble on similar bugs or bugs caused by similar things.
Does that make the games bad? Well, objectively, they are flaws, but in the majority of cases they're things one will rarely stumble upon by himself or that don't really matter, at best a small nuisance. 8-bit jRPGs are still my favourite kinds of RPGs

While my list may seem short, I'm sure if people obsessed over more 8-bit RPGs as they did with those, we'd find more bugs everywhere. Meaning those are only known and obsessed upon because they are in the most famous games. The FF1 situation is similar to younger people listing the bugs in pokémon B/R because they want to "prove" by A+B that their soulless Po-litically-correct-mon is superior.

>I mostly care about translation accuracy
FYI, these would be the versions you want to play if that's most important to you:
FF1: Chaos Rush (seconding Default, maybe w/original font patch)
FF2: Chaos Rush
FF3: Pixel Remaster; Chaos Rush's was made before PR and it's a tweaked script port of the revamped DS remake that doesn't fully work, dunno if he/she ever plans to update it.
FF4: PSP has the least wrong with it, but DS would be better if prose was less flowery. No real equivalent for SFC but I guess the closest would be Fixed Evisceration (Namingway Edition is more popular but takes fanfic-y liberties).
FF5: This is the one I'm not too sure about. The GBA version might be best overall, but it feels like Square was being vindictive at times about their official PSX versions of 4&5 being outshined at the time by unofficial SFC translation hacks, so they overlocalized it to the point a few key scenes almost feel like parody. You'll see some defend these edits, but it's clear in reality that they have trash taste. SFC original does have a GBA script port. The base fan translation is showing its age, but you could try checking out Spooniest's "Legend of the Crystals" addendum instead. It fixes a number of problems with the original fan translation, and the latest 2.x update incorporates parts of the GBA version that aren't embarrassingly dated (to my knowledge).
FF6: hairy_hen's retranslation is undoubtedly the most accurate option. Just be aware that you can't turn off the bugfixes and stuff, but that goes for every relocalization hack, even the GBA script port (which alone is still more accurate than the original).

posts.com:
Not to say there aren't subpar versions of these games (because there clearly are) but I find it a little fascinating how easily you can tell the agerange/experience of people who suggest certain versions of the classic Final Fantasies. You can divide it into at least three major phases:
>1987-2003 (Famicom-PlayStation): The Square Era. The company respects its legacy catelog and may do some QoL here and there for re-releases but otherwise leaves the experience relatively untouched. For oldies.
>2004-2020 (Advance+): The Square Enix Era. The merger fundamentally shifts priorities and the company no longer sees the classic games in the same light, suddenly perceiving flaws that must in some way be "corrected" in each successive re-release, effectively pulling a Lucas except replace George with mostly random employees. For newbies.
>2021-present (Pixel Remaster): The Postmodern Era. In the wake of the abject failure of the later re-releases, the company receives word that pixels are "in" and commissions a new coat of paint that outwardly goes back to the tried-and-true basics, but upon closer inspection carries over much of what was done to these games in the previous phase, creating hodgepodge versions that don't strictly belong in either phase. For plebs.

Pretty much all 2D FF ports and remakes have been done by Tose, all the way from FFIV PSX to FFVI PR. WSC introduced a lot of changes to FF and FFII that have carried over to all the subsequent versions, and WSC/PSX both completely changed the graphics for current tech like the PSP and mobile phone releases. SNES games just got direct ports to PSX (which suck) because the display format didn't change significantly between those two consoles. Similar reasoning as to why FFVII-IX weren't touched until the last decade, since they could just straight up be played on a PS2 and PS3.

>Thief and BM are the worst physical and magic-based classes, respectively, but you can get hella good mileage out of Monk if you dedicate yourself to grinding.
Thief was hit the hardest in terms of bugs. It's supposed to make up for its weaknesses in sheer luck and agility, but in practice, it's a total paperweight. It becomes better after class change, but that's not saying much when even a fourth-rate Knight w/Icebrand can out-damage a first-rate Ninja w/Katana. But in a bugfixed/remade version? Thief becomes MUCH more viable and almost feels like another class entirely, and Ninja's access to Haste and bugfixed Temper means it's not to be underestimated. Meanwhile, both the Black and White Mages are simply too damn squishy even accounting for bugfixed Int, and taking full advantage of them by decking out their magic slots makes them lowkey the most expensive classes to maintain, so they're hardly worth wasting slots. This ironically makes the default party of the NES/MSX version the best beginner-friendly one in the long run since it has the most reasonable variety; in the original/bugged version, Thief is just too much of a drag in the long run and you're better off replacing it with literally anything else. I dunno why remakes then swap out Monk and Red Mage for White and Black Mages. That's just a straight-up worse setup even in those versions. All the good magic can be learned by Red Wizard, and physical stats are way more important in this game, so it's a nobrainer. Overall, Warrior>Monk>Red>Ninja>Black/White>Thief.

>>9585613
> All the good magic can be learned by Red Wizard
Due to the way the magic scaling works in remakes, doubling in base power at thresholds of 20, 30, 40, 50 etc., the Red Wizard will have what amounts to base level magic power of the NES/PSX versions still when nearing level 50, not breaking 30 until or after that point, while the Black Mage has gotten 1~2 extra layers of damage at any one point in the game. Then there's the overpowered healing items, standard MP system and other changes that change the game in a major way.
There simply is no need for Black Magic outside of Haste and Temper in the later versions due them being based on the easy version of PSX. The abundant healing items and overinflated leveling speed means that you're not in danger of being whittled down, and any damage your fighters deal is enough to one shot enemies, while your MP dependent mages will be either barely missing out on kills. For bosses you Temper/Haste/Giants glove the Master and one or two shot the bosses, save for Chaos. Even the Lich is handled easily with Diaga spells from your White Mage.
Personally I go for
>NES/PSX: Knight, Master, Red Wizard, White Wizard
>Later Versions: Knight, Master, Ninja, White Wizard.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9599362
>It really suffers from DQ's problem of locations on the map being completely fucking pointless after you do the Quest of the Day.

That is a good point, and something they lost from DQ2. In DQ2 towns tend to work like hubs from which you may lead several adventures, and come back to between these adventures: using Cannock to go to the cave in the east, then to the cave in the west, before venturing further. Using Hamlin to go to Moonbroke, find the item in the swamp, then the tower in the east before venturing further. Then of course using Tantegel as a base for going to Chamlock and the initial sea exploring; and I think Beran tends to present itself as the final base for the end game events.
Plus you do tend to have reasons to come back to this or that town for Y or X reasons

Everytime I think about DQ2's design, my favourite in the series, I find something new to say about how well designed or influencial it was and how criminally underrated it is. It seems to better regarded in Japan as they know that is the game that started DQ mania, DQ clones and tons of tropes and mechanics for the entire genre, while over here it is easily dismissed between DQ1 and 3. Of course, the west got DQ2 much later.

FF1 sort of followed DQ2's way to using towns as a hubs but in a lighter way. Then sadly, after DQ3's success, everyone started copying what DQ3 did, whether those things were improvements or not, and we got lot's of RPGs consisting of "enter new area with 1 town, 1 dungeon, move to next area with 1 town, 1 dungeon, repeat"

I like blurry pixels because it's what I remember the games looking like when I was a kid. I'm either the oldest zoomer or the youngest millennial but I had a small CRT in my bedroom while growing up and I had a SNES, N64, and Gamecube hooked up to it through composite and I remember what it looked like pretty well because I played on that thing until I moved out of my parents house. I do actually play on a modern TV but I connect all of my consoles through a RetroTink 5X and I adjust the settings per console to find the ideal look. There's a lot of shitty CRT filters in RetroArch but I think the custom options that exist on the RetroTink are actually really good and can produce a nice image. I'm excited to see where they go with this in the future with the 4K model because it's really pretty convincing. My friend has a PVM and I've even fooled him with pictures of it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9599906
70s-80s chips were often NMOS logic. This is when all the transistors in the chip are n-doped. It has the disadvantage of using a lot of power and getting hot as it forces every transistor in the chip to draw current even when idling, and it also produces a lot of signal line noise and can have glitchy behavior due to how the logic works.

All modern chips (anything designed in the last 30+ years) are CMOS logic, which is a mix of p and n-doped transistors. It is much more efficient and cooler running as idling transistors do not use any power and it's free of signal line noise and glitches. However it was not widely used for years as it was more complex to manufacture and early CMOS chips were very slow (solved when they found they could just thin the metallization layer). CMOS chips are less forgiving of sloppy system design as they can be damaged by a bus conflict as that will drive the signal lines on the chip high, while NMOS signal lines would go low.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I like it. It can be a bit tricky to figure out the strategy. As long as you remember you are supposed to be a tiny elite group of whatever your side can pull together, and you are fighting against a virtually unlimited army, then it gets a lot easier to figure out what you should be doing. It's not a TBS game where you can afford to lose units. Losing even one unit is a massive disaster, and will handicap you for a few future missions if you continue on. There is no acceptable level of losses, there is no acceptable level of damage. Know exactly where you need to go, move fast, hit hard and fast, get out fast. All other tactics are suicide.
I remember the 1st mission being that easy "blow the dam" mission, and the 2nd being your own private slice of Vietnam where winning or losing was entirely dependent on your ability to use artillery and bombing jets. Then I remember something about a real difficulty curve of a mission where you can only bring 4 or 6 people for a jail-break for some VIP. Everything after that is kinda blurry except that bastard of a final mission. Had a full team armed to the teeth, and still barely pulled that one off.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Considering Saturn was a failure outside of Japan, I'd say Dreamcast.

No one in the USA cared about the Saturn in the 1990s. It was a joke to a majority of people. If you went into a game store, it was either Nintendo 64 or Playstation 1 that dominated store shelves. Most stores didn't have a Sega Saturn display section. And if they did, it was tiny and shoved near the clearance section. Saturn was overpriced and just a terrible selection of games in the USA. No Sonic either. How stupid. No one cared about Saturn. And it just died and wasn't even remember by most kids.

Dreamcast at least had hype. I remember retailer's carrying the system and hyping it up. Selling special edition versions like the Black Dreamcast and other colors. It was a big deal. Too bad about Sega going bankrupt (because apparently Saturn drained their finances too much), but Dreamcast sold 3x the amount of the Saturn in half the amount of time. Much more memorable games too. Crazy Taxi, Soul Caliber, Sonic adventure, etc. If only Sega didn't run their business into the ground I'm sure Dreamcast would have done respectable for itself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9589170
If you had to choose between the Saturn or the Dreamcast for playing games on the original hardware than the clear choice is the Saturn. The Dreamcast is a great system, but the majority of its best games have been ported or re-released on other platforms, whereas the majority of the Saturn's best games are exclusive to the console.

Saturn consoles are still fairly cheap as well, you can get a jap import model with a controller, a memory cart, and sometimes a game or three for around $100 shipped. Spend another $50 on a PseudoSaturn cartridge and you'll be able to play burned games. Alternately you can get an ODE fairly cheaply (from around $140 to around $220, depending on the model).

The Dreamcast can play burned games natively since the copy protection was cracked over 20 years ago, but since the DC supported GD-ROMs (essentially CDs that could store 1GB of data compared to the 700MB you could get out of a CD-ROM) a significant portion of the games on the system have to have data trimmed to make them fit on a CD-R. This usually means stuff like video being heavily downsampled, audio being downsampled, or sometimes audio/video being removed completely. The ODE situation on the Dreamcast is kinda fucked as well (they exist, but availability can be a pain in the dick if you don't want to buy the more expensive model).

Either console will have a solid selection of arcade ports, RPGs, and action games. Neither console had a ton of lightgun games - the Saturn basically has a couple of solid Virtua Cop games, a mediocre port of House of the Dead, and the typical Maximum Force/Area 51 combo (plus a few not stellar others), meanwhile the Dreamcast has a great port of House of the Dead 2 and Confidential Mission (plus a couple more gun sections in other games). Columbine happened in early '99 and basically tanked any US releases of lightgun games for a few years, so the DC got almost none.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9597751
>The Dreamcast was a failed hail mary from it inception.

It's pretty sad, because the Dreamcast was basically designed to fix every single problem that developers had with the Saturn:

> The multi-processor architecture on the Saturn is a pain in the ass to code for and port games from other consoles to
The Dreamcast was built with a single powerful CPU
> We needed to utilize the RAM cart to get the best performance because of the low amount of memory, a peripheral that wasn't even released outside of Japan
The Dreamcast shipped with 16MB of RAM, an insane amount for a console in 1999
> It's difficult to get high quality 3D graphics out of the console
The Dreamcast shipped with a powerful GPU, 8MB of VRAM for high quality textures, and hardware antialiasing (meaning AA was essentially "free")
> People were turned off by the Saturn's high pricetag at launch
The Dreamcast launched at half the price of the Saturn, and two thirds the expected price of the PS2
> Coding games for the Saturn is difficult due to the low quality official documentation
Sega made a point to have extensive and widely available hardware documentation for developers
> Porting games from the PC to the Saturn is difficult to impossible
The Dreamcast shipped with WindowsCE support to make porting games from the PC to the console easier (if developers chose to utilize it)
> Coding online multiplayer for Saturn games wasn't worth the time and money spent due to low sales of the Netlink (mostly due to its high cost)
Every Dreamcast launched with a 33.6k or 56.6k dialup modem, and support for a broadband adaptor
> Supporting 3 or more players in games is a waste of time due to the low sales of the multi-tap
The Dreamcast shipped with four controller ports

Pretty much the only steps backward from the Saturn were no onboard save storage, and the controller (losing the 3x2 arcade layout in exchange for a 2x2 diamond as well as using only a single analog stick).

>>9600024
That guy is trying to bait the thread, it's not a serious post.

I do wonder what THPS would have been like on the Saturn though. The control scheme would have to be something like B to ollie, A for kick tricks, C for grab tricks, and Y to grind, with L and R being used for rotations. That would leave X and Z, I don't know if there is anything else that would be useful to be mapped there. Skipping music tracks maybe?

The major thing with a THPS port would be that the framerate would have to be solid. It has Steep Slope Sliders, which runs well, as well as a couple other Japanese snowboarding games. I think it would be doable. The PS1 version has a few large open levels, but it also has very aggressive fogging to keep the draw distance down.

Getting THPS2, 3, and 4 running on the console would have been a struggle I think though. With THPS2 the skater models and skater/environment textures had a huge increase in quality (THPS3 and 4 on the PS1 are basically just reskins of THPS2 with new moves).

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9596485
The grades exist to nudge you into playing the game in a way that will be more fun and skillful. It's basically an informal difficulty selection, if you're okay with getting a sub-par rank on every level the game will be easier but less satisfying, just like as if you had played on easy.

Anyway, there are benefits to being considerate about how you attack but I'll grant you don't NEED to do it to beat the game, but even so you need to do things besides button mashing to avoid damage, unless you just tank it all with items but again that's playing on babby mode and an impractical playstyle that's essentially equivalent to skipping the gameplay.

That said, I do kinda get the sense this genre pushes you much harder to learn how to properly defend than it does how to attack. Learning how to deal a lot of damage, combo, or improve your style rank/score is all a lot more optional than learning how to not get hit, and I think it can contribute to these games feeling more button-mashy on a casual level. Something that also bothers me about them is that for all the hype around sick combos, a lot of the enemies can't be meaningfully combo'd. Humanoid bosses in particular can often be stunned, allowing you to wail on them for a bit, but no matter what you do to them during these sections they just sit there: you can't move or manipulate them in any way, all you can do is deal damage. It's lame - I'm not saying you should be able to infinitely combo them, but if they're going to have a "vulnerable" state you can trigger, make them comboable when in that state.

>>9590557
The date scenes are almost too subtle for their own good. The game is amazing at narrative subterfuge, setting up the audience for a love triangle only to hint that there's something more going on. The language implies lovey dovey but the underlying meaning is way more straight forward. Aeris tells Cloud that he doesn't have to pretend to be someone else and that she'd rather meet the real person. Again, like a big sister telling her kid brother to stop pretending to be something he's not. With Tifa's date she tries to say something and backs off. She says "Aeris would be able to say it" or something along those lines. You think that it's an attempt at a love confession but it's really Tifa trying to confront Cloud about his bullshit and Tifa is acknowledging that Aeris is way more assertive than she is. Both girls are trying to use the date to have an intervention and the love triangle gimmick is the smoke and mirrors to disguise it to the player.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think she's more important to Cloud based on his memories of his mother, where his flashbacks of her in Nibelheim are probably his most authentic. This makes the most sense because he never really knew or understood Zack's parents in Gongaga to really appropriate, and even when you do meet them, they act very different from Cloud's memories of his mother. Meanwhile, that Cloud in the flashbacks with his mother is probably the truest version of Cloud we see until the actual reveal come last disc.

She tells him to look for an older woman who can keep him in line, and Aeris does happen to be older, and while that isn't important, I do think the conversation hints more at why he's drawn to Aeris and the way she talks to him, even if that kiddish honesty of hers isn't exactly romantic and more arm's length, which is a luxury Tifa lacks and explains why she can never get to the point with him and can only say nothing at all for a long time.

I like the Cloud and Aeris pairing, but I don't think they were ever romantically drawn to one another. Cloud at most probably relates her to his mother, and that's why losing her feels hurts, but his inability to protect Tifa hits him so differently in comparison, he has to completely compartmentalize and repress the fact until he's no longer allowed to.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9597079
the big mistake NEC made with bringing the PC Engine over to the US as the TurboGrafx 16 is that they wasted so much time and money on redesigning the system for the American market to be bigger when they should have used the PC Engine's tiny size as a selling point, market it as not only the video gaming equivalent to the Walkman or one of the Portable Computers of the era, but not wasting a bunch of time redesigning it also means they probably could have gotten it onto the US market in 1988 instead of 1989 giving them time to build up market share instead of having to immediately compete with the Sega Genesis and this also means that NEC could have honestly marketed the TurboGrafx at launch as being the legitimately most powerful gaming system in the US as it outperforms the NES in almost every respect(indeed I picture a lot of the marketing of this alternate TurboGrafx that maintains the original PC Engine design highlighting it's small size of both console and it's HuCards as being more advanced than the NES and it's cartridges being comparatively huge but having worse graphics)

there's no beating out a Nintendo that's successfully launched the NES in the US but NEC could have easily secured the 2nd place slot for a few years if they hadn't been dumb and wasteful and that in turn could have allowed them to hold onto being a console maker longer than in OTL

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9600497
>>9600510
>>9600551
1. PC-E has a fast 8-bit CPU while the Mega Drive has a slightly less fast 16-bit CPU with 32-bit data width. The 65C02 assembly codes resemble that of the 6502 and have shorter and simpler commands than the 68000, thus it excelled at simple 2D tasks. The 68000 excelled at more complex tasks, allowing games to have more visual effects and even 3D rendering capability. It's just like comparing the 6502 to the Z80 or the 680.
2. PC-E's display controller is more straightforward from what I know. Yeah it could render more colors, but you couldn't have too much parallax effects, and 3D effects would be slower. And I think you could pull off some tricks on the MD to make it display more colors.
3. PC-E's 8KB scratchpad SRAM might have helped. The Mega Drive got a slower 64KB unified DRAM.
4. Japanese devs sucked at 68000 assembly, or they just didn't bother trying because the MD was much less commercially successful in Japan. The Amiga veterans working on Mega Drive games created tons of technically impressive games the PC-E couldn't even dream of running. There's nothing remotely comparable to Turrican 3, Duke Nukem 3D, and The Lost World on the PC-E. There are a few great looking Japanese MD games like Panorama Cotton, Ranger X, and Alien Soldier. Faceball's 4 screen multiplayer is pretty impressive though, but it's a horrible looking game, worse than the Atari 8-bit port.
5. Space Harrier looks like ass t.b.h. Outrun looks and runs better on the mega drive.

The Mega CD was essentially just Sega shitting themselves over getting completely destroyed by NEC/Hudson. In 1991, you could buy a Mega CD. It had 2 dogshit third party launch titles. Alternatively, you could buy a PCE Duo, which had already been out for a few months, for much cheaper than a MD+MCD combo. And you could play acclaimed titles that had been released over the past 3 years of development.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9578442
>>9578523
Yup, innovations tend to fail.
While some wanted pinballs as wide as pool table, Lawlor created a mini-pinball, with a goose game on the front panel. It was time-based: you had no balls limit, the game would keep giving it back to you until you ran out of time, and you had to complete objectives to get extra time. It was really fun, and it completely failed.

posts.name: Anonymous

The somewhat rare Jersey Jack Pinball Pirates of the Caribbean pinball machine also has a cannon. You shoot the ball onto the mini-playfield pirate ship that rocks back and forth, and then you load the ball into the cannon. >Can I plug them in?
Why, yes. Especially if you're looking for an alternative way to heat your home.
>Will such old machines have problems if I just plug them back in after many years or not being used?
Probably. But there are just a couple of things to check. Remove the backglass, open the front panel, and find the batteries. Acid is most likely leaking from them straight down on the motherboard.
Also check out the fuses (also in the panel). Just make sure they all work, if needed replace them BUT respect the manual. Don't put slow blow in fast blow and vice versace.
>What would be the best way to sell them?
Keep them.

https://pinside.com/pinball/forum/topic/varkon-club/page/3#post-6628631

Found this post saying he was offered 20k for a restored Varkon (aka a Varkon in very good condition), so 10K for a bad one seems increasingly possible.
The hype thing with sealed videogames is sort of a separate issue from anything going on with pinball. The arcade buying world and the collectible videogame buying world are two different worlds. Even the arcade world and pinball world are kind of different.

There was a pinball auction in California that was covered in the NYT where a bunch of pins were sold to various uninformed people on the internet for way more than they would typically go for, but that's just typical for any auction, I think. But aside from that, new and used pinball prices have been going up, and not in any illusory way.

Part of the reason Varkon is valuable, apart from rarity, is that people like the gameplay and theme. There are a lot of rare games that are not that valuable because people don't care for the gameplay/theme.

The true number of Varkons that exist is probably less than 90 btw, since some of them were converted into arcade (videogame) cabinets. And of course, some of them were probably scrapped.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9581778
It's a reasonable choice for number 1, I'd say. It's by Keith Elwin, who was the greatest pinball tournament player for longer than anyone and now is an extremely popular pinball designer. And Godzilla is his most recent game, and it's seemingly universally liked by everyone.

As for what's so good about it:
The playfield is innovative, and the experiment is successful, I'd say. Lots of careful attention paid to geometry. Some interesting stuff that's either never been done before or hasn't been done in this way.
The code is good. Lots of breadth and depth. Not sure what else to say about it, other than that it's full of clever original wrinkles like a lot of other games (particularly Elwin games maybe), but moreso.
People like the theme. As do I.

Chicago Gaming Company:

Cactus Canyon (trickling out slower than anticipated due to production issues or something)

Gottlieb made a modern version of El Dorado called El Dorado City of Gold

Jersey Jack has gone back and rereleased their old games before. Wizard of Oz, mostly.

Stern does Vault editions of their old games sometimes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9589668
Nudging and tilt bobs (or tilt alarms as you call them) predate flippers. You're talking about something that was introduced before Paul McCartney was born, so it doesn't really make sense to use the word "finally". If the operators don't want people to nudge they can tighten the tilt and/or reduce the number of warnings, and a few do. That's their prerogative.

I don't need to nudge to have a good time, but for a lot of players it enhances their enjoyment of the game, and operators allow nudging because they believe that the increased earnings from nudge-loving players outweighs the cost of extra repairs. Or they simply consider nudging part of the game as well and don't want to eliminate it.

>>9589646
The underlying reality is that pinball machines were designed to steal quarters from kids much like slots from adults, and that kids would use nudging to stay in the game. They added tilt to prevent this and keep the quarter stealing going. When they started making tables for home use, quarter stealing became less of a design focus, but nudging stayed. Personally, I don't really nudge because I think the game is more fun when your skill should solely come from being able to manage the ball with flippers, but I understand why people nudge because its inherent in the nature of a physical game like pinball.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9591112
You seem to be misunderstanding something. Nudging is not something the general public does to machines. It's someone only very specific players do. And Nudging, shifting, or moving the machine *will* cause issues over time. They loosen screws, bolts, and wear out the machine connections at joints. It's a physical movement of the machine afterall. Maybe not cause issues right away, but it will over time.

I've even seen instances where a player nudges too hard and can cause cracks in the glass. Do these people take responsibility? Nope. They just quietly walk away and leave the arcade without saying anything. Now the arcade owner has to pay to replace the glass. And the pinball is now out of service for days or weeks depending on how quickly they replace the glass.

Nudging (or any other "pro" pinball techniques) causes problems over time when a single player does it. Now imagine a pinball machine in a public arcade. It gets played dozens of times a day by many different players. More if it's popular location. It wears out the machine faster. Pins are just pieces of wood and metal after all. It's gonna break eventually if you keep stressing the connection points with movement.

You might be able to get away with it with newer machines but These older pinball machines aren't made anymore and sourcing replacement parts are difficult if something serious breaks. They should be respected and treated with an extra level of care from players if it's an older machine. This isn't the 1980s or 1990s anymore. These machines are old now.


Personally, I'd much rather focus on flipper control than worry about nudging and shifting a machine. If I have to nudge then it means I took a bad shot and misjudged the ball angle. A nudge is like admitting I failed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9593672
>Pinball games are a family of games in which a ball is propelled into a specially designed table where it bounces off various obstacles, scoring points either en route or when it comes to rest. Historically the board was studded with nails called 'pins' and had hollows or pockets which scored points if the ball came to rest in them. Today, pinball is most commonly an arcade game in which the ball is fired into a specially designed cabinet known as a pinball machine, hitting various lights, bumpers, ramps, and other targets depending on its design. The game's object is generally to score as many points as possible by hitting these targets and making various shots with flippers before the ball is lost. Most pinball machines use one ball per turn (except during special multi-ball phases), and the game ends when the ball(s) from the last turn are lost.

>>9597036
>For the nudge, no nudge argument i do think nudging is completely viable
The problem is that the argument is based on:

"I will do whatever it takes to win. I don't care or give af."

Your starting point for the argument is that "you want to win" . So your whole argument is just logical fallacies and justifications on why your questionable actions should be allowed.

But your starting point should be "I should respect the machine and not abuse it".
That should be the starting point for everything. Because if you break it, then you are responsible.

>and if it takes 15 years for the leg to not work anymore and require repairs that is a testament to build quality of machines.

This makes no sense. First of all Most pinball machines are not brand new. Are you going to pay for the damage caused if you "nudge" a machine and (that rare situation happens) the leg gives out? Or if you crack the glass?

Let me also add there is no defined version of "nudging". Movement that might be acceptable to you might be completely understandable to the pinball machine owner.

Other anon said he saw someone lift and slam a pinball machine and called it nudging. Tournaments can get heated too. These pinball machines are Electro-Mechanical machines. Not arcade machines. That means abuse will knock things out of alignment or calibration over time.

>But if the games themselves by design allow you to nudge to a certian degree before it locks up, wouldnt that be encouraging the mechanic as a risk/reward system?

I don't think you understand what "by design" means. Pinball Manufacturers have never promoted moving the machine during play.

Manufacturers noticed people were physical shaking, lifting, and slamming the machine to keep their ball alive. The tilt mechanism was added as a "penalty" for the players.

The tilt mechanism was NOT added as a "challenge" to players. They aren't challenging players to 'see how much they can shake the machine without triggering tilt'.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9597367
>logical fallacies and justifications on why your questionable actions should be allowed

As someone who has been to plenty of arcades, pinball tournaments, and talked with arcade owners at local places, usually there is a general consensus on what a proper nudge and what is allowed is. You can look at tournament rules for most places and there usually is defined "what you cant do" that is present when you enter tournaments such as picking up the machine. Usually there is a clear difference between nudging and straight up abusing the machine. Slapping the sides does not equal picking it up. Of course every place is different but it usually is a general consensus of "nudging will happen, just dont be stupid".

>are you going to pay for damages?

Highly depends. If a freak accident like a leg break happens or window crack id be down to help reimburse them in any way i can if i realized i caused it. But if its a electronic or bug issue, no, cause that is mostly out of my control and just a common thing that happens with new and old machines.

>nudging isnt a risk reward set by manufacturers

I do get what you mean and i actually do agree with you somewhat, however i would reckon if that was completely the case most machines by default would have no warning lockouts.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9597367

>But if the games themselves by design allow you to nudge to a certian degree before it locks up, wouldnt that be encouraging the mechanic as a risk/reward system?

I don't think you understand what "by design" means. Pinball Manufacturers have never promoted moving the machine during play.

Manufacturers noticed people were physical shaking, lifting, and slamming the machine to keep their ball alive. The tilt mechanism was added as a "penalty" for the players.

The tilt mechanism was NOT added as a "challenge" to players. They aren't challenging players to 'see how much they can shake the machine without triggering tilt'.

Giving the player tilt warnings promotes nudging. Some machines replenish players tilt warnings, which promotes nudging.
Example:
Total Nuclear Annihilation gives more tilt warnings for a mystery award.
Jersey Jack's Pirates of the Caribbean lets you gamble tilt warnings to get more in Liar's Dice.
There are probably more I've forgotten.

Also JJP Pirates of the Caribbean has an "escape the locker" hole on the right outlane going to the shooter lane where you can nudge to save your ball. And a crossover return lane.

A lot of machines have unique outlanes that are designed to give you an extra opportunity to save your ball through nudging. Although they do occasionally give you your ball back without nudging, the designers clearly intended them to be used with nudging.

Centaur, Skateball, Full Throttle, Alien, Wheel of Fortune, etcetera.

>Invasion - The Abductors
That one was only published by Midway. It was actually made another studio called Play Mechanix. See, one of the Midway guys decided to start his own company, so it was easy for him to get Midway to publish his games since he knew everyone in the studio.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9595542
its varies quite a lot depending on the size/weight of what youre ordering and where you are. I live in the uk and we now have a free trade agreement with japan so we dont have to pay any customs or import fees outside of the postage unless its over a certain value. If youre in the EU I think you have to pay 20% vat for the import + extra servicing fees. Most recent thing I have ordered was a set of 13 ps2 games and the postage for those is 4000 yen or 30 usd. I ordered a white ps2 recently the shipping for that was 4500 yen or 25 dollars. I dont remember the exact value but i ordered a set of two fat ps3s and the postage ended up being something crazy like 120 dollars but it still worked out cheaper than buying locally as one was a backwards compatible model. Anime figures on average are about 25 dollars postage when i order those. Although it used to be cheaper before the russia ukraine bullshit. Japan post has a postage service called small air parcel which was very cheap and i think i used to be able to get figures shipped for like 10-15 dollars but they cant fly here anymore because they used to go over ukraine. These are all airmail and it will arrive within a week you can get seamail which is cheaper but takes like 2 months or something so ive never tried it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9594753
I see this take being posted a lot more often in recent years, and I couldn't disagree more. I know it's a matter of taste, and if you don't enjoy something I do then that's fine really, but I can't help but feel that a lot of people don't give Sonic a fair enough shot and end up missing out on experiences they might've loved otherwise. When it comes to Sonic, the reason you run into things and get hit is because, well, you're going fast and, depending on how quick your reflexes are, you might not be able to react to things in time, it's something that varies from player to player and that's fine, but I can see why some would go through this and assume that it's all memorization...

Still, all video games require us to memorize sections we're having trouble with, and we're not supposed to be good at a video game as soon as we pick it up, it'd be shallow otherwise, if you could just run and win, then no one would've cared about Sonic, it's a franchise that rewards you for sticking around. One more thing that can help, is that Sonic's vulnerable when he's just running, but not when he's jumping... or rolling into a ball, always make sure to press down in slopes, not only do you gain speed, but you also protect yourself. Also, if you prefer something like Mario, then I can't recommend Sonic's 8bit library enough, they're a lot more Mario like than the original Genesis installments, Sonic 1 is excellent on both Game Gear and Master System, if you go for Sonic 2 then always pick the Master System version, otherwise it's too punishing, but if you go for Sonic Chaos then go for Game Gear, otherwise it's too simple. I hope you can give Sonic another fair shot, but if you prefer not to then that's your choice, but trust me, they're excellent video games.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Dual Analogs are cool but the design of the analog stick housing is really bad. The analog mechanism uses a thin, not keyed (basically around) metal post and there's no reinforcement at all around the slot inside the stick cap. What this means is that the stick can can rotate freely after the slot loosens even slightly which makes it feels weird to use, and inevitably the force of moving it will cause the slot to crack apart and make the analog stick go completely loose. Literally every single Dual Analog I've found in the wild has broken stick caps like that.

IT's really easy to fix thankfully. Disassemble, glue the slot back together, reinforce it with something, and put some glue in the hole to help keep it from rotating when you put it back on the post. I have two Dual Analog controllers and I had to fix both of them like this.

>>9591490
Other way around really. I'd be more inclined to believe that only early adopters of the PS1 even knew about the digital controller. Sony pushed the analog controller very hard after its introduction. System bundles always had the Analog controller after a point and they stopped selling individual digital controllers. The entire reason why the Dual Analog was missing rumble outside of Japan was because they wanted to get it to market faster and cheaper.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9593442
That's the Dual Analog controller, all the differences of note
>Longer handles (Longer than Dualshocks)
>Concave plastic sticks
>R2/L2 buttons have ridges on them in addition to being bigger than they are on the digital controller (same size as Dualshocks)
>No rumble motors outside of japan (if you have donors you can actually solder in appropriate motors into the burger/euro versions and they work fine)
>Analog button actually selects between 3 modes: Digital (Off), Analog (Red light, what you're familiar with), and a flight mode (Green Light, which basically just inverts the sticks to emulate flight sticks)
>The Analog mode can't be automatically set by games unlike Dualshocks you have to do it yourself.

It's a neat controller although the flight mode is ultimately kind of pointless when games could just invert it for you if they bother to have the option. It would actually be pretty convenient if you could use it to invert the analog sticks whenever you wanted but when it's in flight mode it ceases to be recognized as a Dualshock and does nothing unless the game supports the standard PS1 flight sticks such as >>9591962

posts.com:
>old media is DYING
>cartridges won't be around for much longer because THE BATTERIES ARE DYING
SO CHANGE THR FUCKING BATTERIES!! I hate zoomers and poorfags who say shit like this. There isn't a single problem that could occur with cartridge games that can't be repaired so long as you aren't a fucking retard and leave it out in the rain or something.

>Battery dies
Replace it
>Sticker gets messed up
You can get a replacement if you really care
>Data on the chip gets corrupted
It can be rewritten, and you can also replace the chip if you really need to
>save ram dies (problem on games like Sonic 3)
You can replace it with a more modern save ram that will outlive your grandchildren even if you and your kin all play the game daily for the rest of your lives
>Cartridge shelll cracks
This can be repaired, and if it's really fucking bad you can replace the shell
>Capacitor goes bad
Replace it with a new one
Pins get messed up
They can be repaired, or worst case scenario you can remove all of the chips and repopulate them to a new board and Jo you don't need a donor cart for this since you can buy brand new PCB's
>Battery leaks and damages the board
This shouldn't happen if you take care of your games in the first place and also because these batteries last for literal decades, but if it does happen then you can try to clean it or if it's really bad you can repopulate the chips to another board.

And regarding batteries, you can also just outright replace them with save ram chips that will never leak and will last the rest of your life.

So long as you're not a FUCKING RETARD these games will last until long after you and I have left this earth. And if you're not a retard then the only realistic problem that you will ever actually have to deal with is dead batteries and maybe capacitors (but more than likely you will be dealing with capacitors in your consoles, not usually your carts).

posts.com:
> > Data on the chip gets corrupted
> It can be rewritten
Uh, no, it can't. A rom chip is physically burned with the data. The good news is these really don't fail and should outlive you.
You can get a replacement EEPROM chip that is writable with specialized equipment but this requires serious technical skill to operate ancient chip programmers and desoldering abilities.
> and you can also replace the chip if you really need to
not so easy, most of the old carts take 5v chips while everything today is 3.3v, you'd have to add voltage converters to the existing PCBs.

I have over 1000, stupidly--they will all go bad. Many of them are in poor condition just from being played several times. and obviously VHS tape is way more exposed than an NES game, but every single day this shit gets older, so idk why people seem so content to be like "well, it works fine right now!" It's weird how many different groups and different points of interest kind of get folded into retro games, and I believe in the right to repair, I have done several small video game related repairs in my life.

I just think the idea that any of this stuff will last forever is so stupid when we are literally on the eve of total destruction for arcade games. The clock is ticking, and being limited to playing only the games I can physically own and physically play on physical OG hardware seems....well, limiting. All the mainline systems seem like known quantities at this point. There are no more hidden gems to uncover on the NES, SNES, Genesis, N64, Saturn, Dreamcast, PS1, PS2, Xbox, GameCube---it's all out there. Everybody knows. Everybody knows about Team Buddies and Tactics Ogre and Jumping Flash 2 and Snowboard Kids. and I'm not about to spend a fortune importing PC-88 shit, for example. Like I can just not imagine a point in my life where I would plunk down hundreds to thousands of dollars for a single Metal Slug cart on the neo geo. I want to play games. I'm not some baseball card cretin with a basement of sealed and graded baby toys--I want to play games. Limiting myself to what is and has been widely available seems silly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9597901
>>Data on the chip gets corrupted
>It can be rewritten

No it can't, those chips are not re-writable unless you have some rare dev/prototype cart that used EEPROMs, which if that is the case you better have dumped it forever ago.

>and you can also replace the chip if you really need to

Yes and no. There is no way in fuck you will find blanks of the original chips anymore. You can use newer chips, but the pinouts and even size are going to be different so you will have to do a little extra work just to replace the ROM chips.

>>save ram dies (problem on games like Sonic 3)
>You can replace it with a more modern save ram that will outlive your grandchildren even if you and your kin all play the game daily for the rest of your lives

Same issue as above. Yes, it's technically doable, but it's going to be hard to near impossible to find a drop-in replacement and will require some messy hack-ish work.

It's fucking stupid when people complain about the battery dying though, even someone with a $5 soldering iron and first time soldering can replace those.

>And regarding batteries, you can also just outright replace them with save ram chips that will never leak and will last the rest of your life.

Again, same problem as replacing the ROM chip. Also FRAM chips have significantly less durability and speed than SRAM that were used for battery-backed saves. Some games also had SRAM chips to use as additional RAM for the game, not just for saving. Using a FRAM chip like work RAM would tear through it much much faster.

>>9597935
I've had a handful of games die on me. Super Mario World and Mario Paint. But so far all my other SNES and N64 games are ok. I have them all dumped now anyway.

Absolutely. The point of a singleplayer game is to have a fun experience.

The only reason I would NOT use mechanics like this is if the mechanic makes the gameplay unfun or using them is really clunky. Like FEAR has pretty damn cool melee kicks, I use them occasionally even if they aren't all that useful in the end.

Mine was also a 32GB Memory Card. When started to having this problems I just formatted everything and tried to start all over but didn't work. So I swapped for the 4GB Memory Card I had and everything started working fine. Installed Enso on him and passed all the files from a fresh install to the SD2Vita that I bought and made a backup for this files because if anything goes wrong I have a safety. I also removed the Memory Card and didn't install anything so now I have two backups.
In your case you don't need to do all that >>9574464 if you already Enso your Vita using your Memory Card, you can just copy all the files from your Memory Card to the microSD(after you formatted correctly) and swap the ux0: on the YAMT settings and point to the SD2Vita. After that I recommend you to stop using and remove your Memory Card and just leave him as a backup if you didn't make a backup after you hacked your Vita.
Reminder to only do this if you Enso your Vita.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9574813
They designed games around using both screens. Nintendo pushed pretty hard for devs to make use out of the touch screen feature for the lower screen, and this led to quite a lot of square pegs jammed into round holes out of obligation, ergo needless and obnoxious gimmicks foisted on the player. Dawn Of Sorrow comes to mind, the stylus adds exceptionally little to the gameplay, and it actually flows a lot better if you use a romhack which removes the mandatory stylus poking.

Eventually this would be more relaxed, and thus for a lot of games, the second screen didn't serve much more of a purpose other than being something like a map screen, inventory screen, or status screen, which you could manipulate with your stylus if you for whatever reason wanted to take your hands off of the controls.
Those could be pretty convenient and handy in some games, but they also wouldn't have suffered if they only had one screen to work with. Some games were made with the touch screen in mind, such as some drawing games, or Trauma Center, where its application is actually pretty cool and thematically well placed, but most videogames aren't the kind where using a stylus on a screen is a critical or badly needed feature.

So, a gimmick which kind of could be cool for the right kind of games, but which was widely unnecessary. I want to liken it to if the Virtualboy could have been hooked up to a TV to play the games in regular 2D, and then only early games were made with the 3D in mind while most devs just put token efforts in for the 3D and expected you to play it on your TV.

To make this post more retro, the original DS had a slot for GBA slots, of course, so beyond the thing playing DS games, you could play all your favorite GBA games, or pick up later ones for cheaper as the market was moving away from it. Also, some DS games could have some form of interaction with prior GBA titles if two relevant ones were inserted, typically bonuses in a DS sequel to a GBA game.

>>9592401
There's no physical back button by default, so you basically have 3 options:
>swipe up from the bottom of the touchscreen and tap the "Back" triangle on the bar that appears, or do equivalent "Back" gesture if you selected that option under system settings
>hold whatever button combo you set to activate mouse mode (for me it's L2+R2) down for 3 seconds, then press the B button. In mouse mode, the B button is mapped to "Back", and X is mapped to that thing that lets you view all open apps.
>try this https://retrogamecorps.com/2022/01/16/retroid-pocket-2-starter-guide/#Home

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9599010
>>the gun in my picture can literally be set up on a 100” projector. tons of people doing it.
You can set it up on a screen that large, no problem. The issue is the DISTANCE you have to stand away from such a screen, which means the relative size of that screen gets much smaller.

For people who are after the arcade experience, or even a superior one with a bigger screen, your shitty solution doesn't compare. HotD there uses a 45" rear projection screen. It's 66" deep, which means the guns are positioned around 40" from the display, and you can stand quite comfortably at 45" away, with the guns around 20-25" away from the screen. This would be screen size * 0.5, not screen size * 1.5.

The minimum distance you'd be able to stand away with Sinden or any of these shit modern solutions is around 90 inches (68" from barrel). Which is double the distance. Which means the picture you will see will be a quarter the size of what was intended, technically a little smaller because you still need to add in the bezel. This doesn't change if you change the size of the screen, either. You're always limited by the size of the border, which means you will always be forced to stand far further away than is optimal.

>>9596872
>brightness is at about 50% now
That sounds like too much. I have my Trinitron at 3 ticks out of 24 or so, while keeping contrast around the middle of the scale. There is some really slight black crushing, but I get almost true blacks this way.
Remember that "brightness" is the black level setting, and "contrast" is the actual maximum brightness. This has been mislabeled for decades, confusing people to no end. Fortunately some manufacturers have started to change this naming convention to better reflect what those settings do, like LG with their last year OLED models.
Now, to do this adjustment properly you'll need to sit in a dark room and bring out a brightness test pattern of sorts, for example the color bars in the 240p Test Suite. Then you turn down the brightness all the way and make your way up until the bar nearest to black gets barely visible (is a bit brighter than black). Similarly for the contrast, you want to avoid near-white highlights getting blown out, so you should be able to differentiate the value that's nearest to white from pure white. Realistically, you'll probably have to settle on some sort of compromise between true blacks and a bit of black crush as no display is perfect. But hey, that ghosting should be gone at least.

>>9592516
I have been considering this game anew and I want to hear what you guys have to say about the following fault I’ve found with the game: the bosses are often painfully unintuitive for new players. They feature weaknesses that are hard to guess and hard to tell when you’re doing it right versus wrong. For instance, phantoon does his special attack when you super missile him. A new player unfamiliar with his patterns will have a tough time linking that attack to a super missile hitting him and as such will probably stumble through the fight. The worst offender is draygon with the grapple zapple. If you don’t use the grapple against it the fight is really really hard for a new player. Finally, Ridley is practically immune to missiles, taking 180 to die from them as opposed to 20 charge shots, making him not only wall players using regular boss strategies (use missiles and supers) but also doesn’t give any indication that charge shots are doing more (other than noticing the faster color change on him). These bosses seem like an area where the game fails to communicate to the player, unlike the entire rest of the game, which is filled with thoughtful touches.

Thoughts?

MMX is primarily an action game while SM is primarily an exploration/adventure game, so it oughta. The point of MMX is to make you feel like an anime super robot, the point of SM is to make you feel like you're a space soldier travelling through isolated hostile environments, they both succeed

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9599279
>hurr durr you pick up things
are they recorded anywhere? no. do you get game completion %? no.
if you do collect secrets and they are recorded somewhere, then yes, these are technically collectathon elements—"elements" because it's not the key part of the game.
Super Metroid is close to a collectathon, as technically it doesn't require you to collect every upgrade, but it definitely must be a part of the "complete experience".
>>9600005
again, technically, these are collectathon "vibes", but 1) MMX is far more centered on action 2) it has a relatively small number of upgrades, all of which serve other primary function than just be collectibles—you want to get them to get stronger first, not just "to find them".
also,
>you even get rewarded for collecting everything
you get rewarded with hadoken, a very strong weapon. again, while you may want to just get it for the heck of it, there's also a very significant (if not higher) worth in its function.
MM&B has far more obvious collectathon element in the form of CDs, though again it's still more of a side thing to do in the game, never required to progress anywhere.
on the other hand, Super Metroid is pretty much all about finding secrets, it's generally the main focus of the game, and while technically all the extra missile / super missile / power bomb upgrades do serve a function, each following added one has relatively small functional value—you look for them mostly just to find them, and only to small extent to get stronger.
it's not quite a full fledged collectathon. it's never quite spelled in your face that you must collect stuff, like eg in Banjo; the items do have SOME function, and getting a particular number of them isn't required to progress anywhere (like eg "get 10 missile upgrades to pass"), but it's pretty damn close.

posts.name: Anonymous

>it has a relatively small number of upgrades, all of which serve other primary function than just be collectibles—you want to get them to get stronger first, not just "to find them".
MMX is a SIGNIFICANTLY shorter game than Super Metroid, so yeah it has less upgrades. As for the power of each upgrade being supposedly more significant than those in Super Metroid, it hardly matters. In Super Metroid there is much more ground to cover in between bosses, so it doesn't matter if a single missile upgrade doesn't make you significantly stronger, the point is you WILL be significantly stronger over time, it's not "just to find them", sure if you want to 100 percent the game at that point you're basically treasure hunting but that's just more content in the game... If you collect no missiles, or extra health tanks, you're going to have a very difficult time beating the game unless you're a seasoned pro, just like in MMX. Not to mention you actually need certain upgrades to progress through the game as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
