>>9587326
I think it's an issue of standards changing. Nowadays, you'd get an E10+ or T rating from those elements. In the late '90s, however, people seemed to just care less about the degree of violence that appeared in children's media. So, you could get away with a little blood and death, especially if it was subtly put in.

The clearest example of "they could never get away with that today" in an E-rated game I can think of is Mega Man X4. One cutscene has a character slash some others in half as dark red blood splatters everywhere. Even with the whole "they're robots, so it's not really blood" defense, that scene seemingly got the X Collection a T rating alone.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9597625
You get it right after becoming an adult, and not only does it allow you to progress further, but it unlocks extra exploration potential that you didn't have before. It's the item that really drives home the point that you're in a whole new phase of the game and much more can be done now. The fact that it can hook onto all kinds of surfaces also makes you want to use it everywhere and see where you can go and what you can find.

So, what happened in later games? In MM, you get it relatively late provided you're following the intended path through the game, so while it's just as capable as the OoT Longshot, by that point you've probably explored most places and the game overall just doesn't reward exploration with it quite as much. In TWW you get it REALLY late and it's MUCH more limited in terms of what it can latch on to, so there's close to nothing to do with it past using it in the few places you're meant to use it in the last few dungeons. In TP, while the concept of the Clawshot is cool and doubly so when you get the second one, again, in practice you can only really use it on places you're specifically meant to use it, so exploration potential with it outside of dungeons boils down to finding compatible targets scattered here and there. Likewise with SS, despite the fact you get the double Clawshot much earlier there.

tl;dr it's cool in OoT because you get it at a very appropriate point in the game and the game amply rewards you for trying it out all over the place, and later games clamped down on this aspect in favor of railroading you into using it where they want you to use it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9597448
It's an interesting thought exercise, why not have the hookshot in later 3D Zelda titles, or what benefit would adding the hookshot give?

In the case of Twilight Princess and Skyward Sword, instead of a hookshot, you got the "clawshot", which had limited application as it could only pull you to designated markers rather than to given material surfaces.
In Ocarina of Time and Majora's Mask, all the places the hookshot could access were also generally intended, from the right position you could access many spots on a given scene in the game, particularly village rooftops where a secret might be hiding.

Part of changing the hookshot to the clawshot, is that you can no longer rely on commonly placed trees to reach heights.
If you wander around large sprawling maps, the bounds of the playable area usually have large cliff walls which may have trees atop them as decoration. The hookshot would let you get out of bounds too easily, thus the clawshot was introduced to further limit player navigation in a larger world design.

Now, in a game like Breath of the Wild where virtually the entire world map is explorable through air gliding and climbing? A hookshot item wouldn't actually make you able to access any more areas than it previously would, but it might serve to bypass some puzzles or stamina limitations that are in place.
If the hookshot were treated as a tool with durability like bows or rods, it might work; giving the player a chance to quickly reach tricky spots, provide there's a tree or a heavy barrel or something to latch onto.

>>9595983

The strength of Persona games (unlike mainline SMT ones) comes from the characters being interesting as are their private issues that are laid bare as the plot progresses. There's a lot of sin, decadence, perversion and so on that unravels. That's where the main interest lies.

But the obnoxious rate of random encounters and the typical SMT-type dungeon slogs drag it down because they sap away the momentum of the experience. Later games in the series realized that and put more emphasis on the character stuff and reduced the tedium of dungeon crawling.
It's not that the dungeon crawling is bad conceptually, but in each dungeon (or location equivalent) it FAR outstays it's welcome and becomes a chore. This is true in almost every SMT game, but like I said, in Persona games the interest lies in the characters, while in SMT games it's more about the overall atmosphere of the setting.

RPGs were a great genre back then for developers because they didn't have the technical demands that other genres had but still held their own through other means. Super Mario Bros. 3 is way more technically advanced than Famicom Final Fantasy III. Squaresoft at the time never could have made something like Mario 3. Final Fantasy IV is no way as "big" as Street Fighter II. But their RPGs kept pace with the competition because the breadth of the worlds covered for the sacrifices made elsewhere. It's why Lunar exists in the first place. Studio Alex struck out on it's own and settled on an RPG as it's first game. They probably wouldn't have been able to make a fighting game or platformer with the level of competence expected of those genres.

>>9600010
He worked on a couple of them technically:
>Phantasy Star IV
>Genesis
Formally deconfirmed by Sega of America for a while, he pitched it to Japan and got started, Sega of America was interested again and their version released, not WD's. This is keeping in mind Sega had no problem letting him have Sega CD games (Popful Mail) or Saturn games (much, much more).
>Unnamed Hudson Soft JRPG in 1994 (Elfaria?)
>SNES
This one was finished on their end, but WD would provide only the text data while Hudson would do the actual implementation and submission. It's likely Hudson never actually implemented it in a working build, seeing WD have no access to any playable prototype.

The problem with Nintendo was that they were assholes who deserved to go bankrupt for the shit they pulled in the SNES gen, that sunk so many smaller publishers and killed their own SNES third party support.
If you wanted to publish for Nintendo with a complete build, you'd have to mail them the boards (later relaxed to sending the ROM files online) and then hear back from them a month or two later, then you have to place an order. That order will be x2 what you actually need (and they'd buy back from you later unsold stock... maybe). If Nintendo disagrees with the ROM size and minimal sale target you have planned, they will reduce them (and tell you to redevelop the game, that's exactly how they lost Namco and Squaresoft) so in the end the expenses might kill your company before even releasing the game. That got relaxed at the end of the SNES gen (even cutting a sweet deal for Capcom who was furious with the SF Zero bomb to recoup loss)

But that stopped with the SNES.
He had GC/XB/GBA/DS/PC to fall back on and actively rejected them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you are too good at taking and defending your turf, the game punishes you by taking away any challengers. You have to leave at least one territory for each opposing gang if you want to be able to defend or invade turf again later. Can be somewhat fixed by glitching the game to create turf all over the map, but it's a half-assed solution.
Also, despite taking over the entire city, you really don't gain any benefit for doing it besides knowing there won't be other gangs waiting there to shoot at you. Pretty much everything else in the game will reward you for being good at it, even dancing can come in useful for the dates. Your reward for getting all the turf is no more gang wars to enjoy.

This is really why its cool, though. A dumb kid gets Pikachu and thinks he's gonna be Ash only to be curbstomped by the game mechanics and pressured into actually getting other Pokemon and leveling them up. And you realize how a lot of the game is meant to have a balanced team as well, as a lower leveled mankey or nidoran can hold its own with Onix.

You really won't have that hard a time in RB with any of the three starters. One Charmander has ember he can power through Onix because the special stat isn't properly balanced, and Bide is a normal type move. I've done runs of RB where I just get Charmander and mash A almost the entire game and win. It takes grinding, sure, but its nothing impossible for a kid, which is why so many kids had teams that were anchored on a ridiculously leveled starter.

>>9586809
I think gamefreak didn't want anyone to feel beholden to any of the adaptation's characters as being "right", encouraging kids to play Pokemon their way, pick their own Pokemon, instead of just being like Ash/Satoshi or manga Red or any other Pokespe protags.
This is why all the theories of what Red's personality is like is missing the point to me. Sure, the fan interpretation of Red as this jaded, serious trainer filled with ennui who travels to the furthest regions of the map to contemplate is a cool idea that makes for cool art. But GF seems to have intended to make Red's party one that doesn't make any presumptions about the player's choices. If its Red from yellow, you know he gets the starters/Pikachu
If your team beating the E4 was one overleveled Blastoise and the rest Pikachu, a level 20 Nidorina, a Graveller, and a few otherunderleveled randos, it was just as canon as someone winning with a team of all Legendaries/ubers
Red's team is all Pokemon you were given (and Snorlax, who you need to encounter) in Yellow. Espeon is there so no one takes any of the three RBY Eeveelutions as the "right" choice , and it shows that Red is such a good trainer his Pokemon evolved though his good friendshion(plus, call it autism, but I thought him having an Espeon was a cheeky reference to Gen 1 not having a night time)
The point was it was 3 years later, so most people could have the Pokemon like Red's team. They aren't necessarily the Pokemon he beat the E4 with, given that other returning trainers from the past changed their teams.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9587113
Yes but there's only five HMs. Fly is completely optional and Strength isn't needed until Victory Road (though it unlocks Articuno as well). Flash is sorta optional, but Brock unlocks it so nothing short of a glitched playthrough is ever gonna have a problem with that. Cut is mandatory to get past Cerulean, but Misty unlocks it. Surf only matters for optional stuff, getting to Victory Road, and Cinnabar - and Koga unlocks it. As such, you can fight Lt. Surge, Erika, Koga, and Sabrina in *any* order and can fight Blaine at any point in the line-up so long as it's after Koga. Frankly, the Rockets are a bigger enforcer of linearity than the gyms - you need to clear out the HQ to get the Scope and the Tower to get the Flute.

>>9588249
If you want to play for historic reasons, as >>9588278 noted, Red/Blue would be better. That's the one most fans are familiar with (but less so over time), so you'd understand classic/nostalgic references, including to the original anime. It might feel too slow or dated now, though.
If you want to experience the gameplay in a refined state, I'd skip to a 3rd gen game (as far as I've gone), maybe FireRed or LeafGreen (doesn't matter which), which are remakes of Red/Blue, respectively. Because they're remakes you'd also get most of the big picture elements of the original games, though obviously the experience will vary in a number of ways.
It's definitely playing one to get an idea of why the series is so popular, but the gameplay is highly derivative and the franchise is mostly wasted opportunity, as >>9588270 pointed out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9600812
Balls missing were treated the same way as the number of times a ball shakes before the pokemon breaks free. In gen 1 that animation is actually related to the pokemon's current catch chance, and the ball missing completely basically means the catch chance is about as low as possible, which is why you're most often going to see balls missing if you just huck plain pokeballs at a legendary bird or a chansey,

its a speculation boom. just like comics in the '90s. basically people started finding rare copies that sold for a lot and it became a market around collecting games and hopes that they would one day be worth thousands of dollars.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9593316
>>9593773
Lord, you don't even understand that I wasn't advocating their use, and simply nudged to look at their inception.

Let's get back to mid-90s, when ability to play a video or an animation in a window didn't mean you could automatically do the same in full screen.

https://archive.org/details/CDROMToday11Jan1995/page/n59/mode/2up

Stretching a single bitmap to a different size was not an instant operation, and doing it many times a second could easily exceed both CPU performance and memory bandwidth with all the pixel copying. (Even today a scroll through resized photos in a viewer can be noticeably slower than a scroll through the same files at original size.) Software had to rely on system-provided, driver-provided, or its own optimized scaler functions to be as fast as possible. It often wasn't even proper nearest neighbor scaling, but a block-of-pixel-based assembly routines hard-coded for the specific CPU memory bus width and cache size (or, later, MMX, or, later, SSE), possibly with some fixed dithering.

It is funny that with all the retro circlejerk it's hard to find the video of just a regular video player being used on real hardware. Unique texturing algorithm choices on the first generation of 3D accelerators can give you an idea of speed-optimized scaling results:

https://www.vintage3d.org/images/AT3D/gallery.php
https://www.vintage3d.org/gallery/permedia.php
etc.

Due to hardware limitations, it was still often not possible to do something the straightforward way. Games could use interlaced 120 line video clips to fill the 240 line image because CD-ROM and system performance couldn't handle bigger data streams. When Windows 3.1 media player was told to play the video in full screen, it simply grabbed the video card exclusively, changed the video mode to a smaller and faster one, and bypassed the Windows GUI altogether.

Fast scalers, rotozoomers, and the rest were also important demoscene effects.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9595074
So-called 2D (GUI) accelerators and hardware overlay boards (often with a genlock for external TV signal) that could stretch your bitmaps for you had already existed as a niche professional market. However, it was finally understood that all that multimedia and interactive media often needed to use it on every frame. Video cards began to have dedicated hardware for that (and also began to consume YUV video frames, freeing the CPU from converting each one to RGB after decoding). See how review mentions that the card can stretch the buffer with bilinear filtering (!):

https://archive.org/details/pcworld151unse/page/227/mode/1up

Wow, we have that tiny worse-than-VCD clip playing in full screen with smooth pixels! Of course, bilinear filtering also gives you lots of blur, especially when dealing small bitmaps like NES output buffer.

The problem with hardware stretching is that it is done in hardware. The overlay variant specifically happens after the whole frame buffer is consumed and processed, and treats it like a green screen over which the given image is overlaid (duh). Software couldn't guess how good was the quality of scaling, as computer couldn't even technically get the result back from the screen. Still, it was important to offload as much as possible to the hardware to save CPU performance for the main tasks. Composite and S-Video outputs that later appeared often on regular video cards worked in the same black box manner. How exactly TV picture was generated from output buffer (the whole screen or active accelerated surface) was defined by chip makers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9595076
In addition, a fixed set of desktop resolutions everyone used (640×480, 800×600, 1024×768) did not align well with console screen resolutions. Today you can integer scale that 256×244 to any ratio almost up to 10×. Back then, unless the emulator was a dedicated full screen application, you had to compromise by cutting part of the picture or making it smaller than the desktop (not so great when your monitor was already small). The other alternative was to zoom 2× or 3x, then slightly resize the output, and have either smudged or uneven pixels.

And of course, the aspect ratio of TV console output pixels is not 1:1, so to correct the almost-square picture to (more or less physically correct) 4:3, you had to stretch with different coefficients vertically and horizontally.

On the one hand, hardware scaling on a specific system with a specific hardware using specific resolution could be a blurry mess, a blocky mess, or a combination of both. On the other hand, emulators had to use it in most cases, and had to be prepared for that. The idea of all those 2× and 3x filters was to implement fast enhancing upscale (instead of the regular pixel doubled or pixel tripled copy) that would help contrast lines (e. g. text on screen) to survive the uncontrollable external stretching. They compensated for the less than stellar processing down the path.

posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9595080
You can open any image editor, and try stretching the original buffer, its 2× or 3× copies, and 2× or 3× filtered copies to the same random output resolutions with nearest neighbor and bilinear filtering, and decide which results look less horrible to you.

Then after a couple of years, a couple of processor and video card families, and a couple of DirectX versions letting software interact with hardware through new APIs, it all slowly stopped being relevant. The rest is just wanking. First, some developers decided that all the increased computing power should better be spent on magical algorithms that could convert pixel art into high resolution graphics (they couldn't). Second, clueless users who discovered scaling options mistook them for some important improvements that could be used on their own.

If you have all the modern CPU and GPU performance to produce something that looks similar enough to the original thing, you never need the filters that were used in year 1999 to solve year 1999 problems.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9592669
In each level, you drive around the area with your tank, finding dungeons to enter on foot.
Most of those dungeons are optional, but important so you can upgrade your gun. Although you can very well just find a good place to grind your gun, go back&forth, and then be on your way.
One of the dungeons in each level has a boss which gives you an upgrade for the tank (like a new weapon or hover or driving on walls etc), necessary to unlock the path to the next level, and so on.

You can strafe by holding the bomb button.
Try to always have your gun max'd out before a boss, I know it's not easy. Some higher gun levels are actually shittier than earlier ones too because of poor hit detection. If all else fails, find a good spot to spam grenade on a boss.

Other protips: some of the levels loop on themselves, or have shortcuts that teleport you to another area. It makes some levels more confusing than they should be (level 2 is actually the worse)
You only have 3 lives, 4 continues. Infinite continues in the JPN version. It's actually pretty hard to beat the game in 4 continues, you have to know where to go, I only did it after beating the JPN version.
At some point once you get a certain upgrade, you'll find there is nowhere to go with the tank. You have to think Metroid and backtrack to an earlier level.

Honestly play both (specifically OG Metafight for >>9590696 reasons). Blaster Master Zero gives you the outward impression of being a stright remake of the first game with its opening area and returning enemies, but then it throws a curveball and the series turns out to be a brilliantly subverted Metafight sequel.
...Oh, you wanted to dabble in the older sequels? Don't. The series was passed around Z-teams and didn't go anywhere until Zero, so you're better off ignoring them. The PlayStation game may be worth checking out if you want some context for a few story elements in Zero 2&3, and MAYBE try the GBC one if you just want more BM-otherwise, do yourself a favor and avoid the Western-made shovelware.

I am also gay and sentimental like you guys and this is how I solved that problem:

Whatever name I give to the my first three monsters, I give to their offspring as well. That way Dan is always with me even if he's an anteater or a gas dragon. I never let my first three buddies breed with each other since they have to keep their lineage pure. Then at the very end of the game, on the final tournament round, I breed back to get my original monsters, now with like +20, insane stats, and like 12 generations of movesets. So my three buddies I fought the first round are now back with me, though in truth, they were never away from my side the entire game. I fucking love you guys, Dan the Anteater, Vlad the Drackee, and Hale the Healer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9600508
How do the Joker games play in comparison?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9600596
You can have some monsters in your party in reserve, scouting new monsters is done by making all your monsters attack one and the more damage they do the higher the chance of it working, there's a size system where you can get giant kaiju-sized monsters that attack multiple times, hold more skills, and have bigger stats, and breeding is a lot more customizable.
Most combinations give you 3 monsters and not only can you choose which one you get you can choose which three skills are passed down. And instead of passing down individual attacks, you pass down skill packs that grant the monster moves, traits, and stat bonuses when you spend skill points on them which you get by leveling up.

posts.com:
I have made a musical discovery regarding an old favorite: The "drugstore" (weapons, items etc) music from Earthbound is modeled on "Maxwell's Silver Hammer", by The Beatles. Although they are musically distinct, they have a clear similarity:

-Both melodies are these happy, mid-tempo, plodding but slightly subversive things.
-The pitch goes jauntily up-and-down in both cases.
-the ending of each "verse" is unmistakably the same. Try singing "sure that she was dead" to the ending of the drugstore music before it repeats again (the drugstore take adds two beats after this)
-the developers were clearly into the Beatles, per an early in-game Onett joke.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mJag19WoAe0
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OOXFR5SQnYk

posts.sub: How come decades later most sword games still miss basic inputs like this?
posts.com:
Spin stick and time your attack to do a spin attack, tilt stick forward and attack to stab, tilt stick right and attack to swing right, tilt stick left to attack to swing left, hold attack to charge, etc. Especially the spin always feels so good and right to do

It's the first thing I test in games with swords and more often than not you can't do anything. Examples are Prince of Persia, Fable, Genji, Crystal Chronicles or even Souls games today

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9594662
It has to do with the speed of the combat and how mobile the character is.

In something like Bayo or Ninja Gaiden you're so much more faster and agile that it wouldn't feel well. Zelda games and Maximo are much slower in combat and you move a lot less. There are sometimes inputs that use the 360 but between 2 different attack buttons, fast enough frame data to make use of pauses (eg A,A vs A,wait,A), and the many ways you can dial up an attack there is no reason to resort to these inputs which as I said are going to feel bad with how fast and agile these newer characters are.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
N64 was the "tech demo" phase for a lot of this stuff. Really showing up all of the different ways a character can control in a 3D space, and all of the different things you can do with an analogue stick in gameplay.

After that, we move into the stream-lining phase, where developers are thinking less about what the player "could" do, and thinking more about what most players are going to want, which is simplicity of controls and mechanics. That's either a good or a bad thing, depending on how you view it.

Seems like it was very common for an N64 game to have different movement speeds, climbing, swimming, crawling, ledge grappling, first person view modes, and flight all baked into the design, while a modern game like Elden Ring might not necessarily have even half of those options.

Gonna paste this from another thread since you clearly have brainworms and couldn't tell your shit from your trousers:

Sephiroth was already insane, he just found a satisfying rationalisation. It's evident even before he goes postal that he's a messed up dude, he ain't a compassionate guy who makes friends, he's a sociopath who exists to be nothing more than a weapon. Sephiroth was previously a war hero before who defended civilians because that's what the mission asked of him; he doesn't have those guidelines anymore—he is on a literal pilgrimage to kill them.

One of the worst things Crisis Core did was try to make Sephiroth a compassionate bloke.

>>9599512
After becoming an adult and getting into classical music, the series' growing pretensions from 6 onward make me think they were actually trying to create interactive operas.

Operas often only change scenes at the beginning of a new act. So to tell a complete narrative in 3-5 scenes, exposition dumps are a big part of it. It can sometimes be like an episode of Springer with a dynamic soundtrack that reacts to two characters having an argument over something that happened offscreen and the details slowly emerge as they yell stuff at each other accusingly, for example. If you imagine the flashback scenes as the group talking to one another, and Uematsu's music being written to pull you into caring about the sudden left turn of the narrative, it makes sense.

I'm not saying its brilliant or that there wouldn't be a better way to do it, but as the series got more serious, its pretty obvious that they considered opera an artistic aspiration for the series and now that I'm familiar enough with the tropes of Wagner and Italian Verismo operatic storytelling, the way 6 onwards delivers story beats feels similar to the way Puccini (Aeris' death) or Wagner (giant, world ending sword duel climax) would present them.

>>9599610
Good post. Most FF fans are completely artistically illiterate and can't see any nuance. Sephiroth is shown to be cold and ruthless even when he was a "hero." He was raised to be a killing machine, held up as a figurehead for Shinra's propaganda, showered with praise for slaughtering any perceived enemy, and we learn from Lucretia that he was never even held by his mother as a baby; he was whisked off by scientists to be a research specimen the moment he was born. You don't need to be a psychologist to see how fucked up someone would be from living a life like that. Even before the Nibelheim incident, he was, at best, a functional sociopath with a massive superiority complex, but most players completely miss all of that and take the claim that he's a hero at face value.

I'd also argue that he doesn't actually give a shit about Jenova or the Ancients. Those are just post-hoc rationalizations he uses to justify his desires. When he reads in Gast's research notes that Jenova is an Ancient, he claims that entitles him to take the planet back from the humans who betrayed the Ancients. Later, when he travels through the Lifestream and learns the truth about Jenova (that she was actually just a monster that wiped out the Ancients), he twists it around and says that he's entitled to rule the planet because Jenova was even greater than the Ancients were. In other words, all he really wants is to satisfy his own ego by elevating himself up to godhood compared to the rest of the world, and he'll use whatever excuse he can come up with to justify it.

>>9600431
Its cool being able to understand the references when you notice them. Curtains Down from Blood Money is a lot more satisfying when you understand the context of the scene the target is playing out, for instance.

The opera is called Tosca, and thats the ending scene. There's at least a dozen Kojima-tier absurd plot twists that precede it, but basically the character being executed believes that its a mock execution, because the chief of police pardoned him but had to keep up appearances because he's known for being tough on crime. Usually on stage, that character acts like a chad with no fear of death, and his girlfriend is singing these joking lyrics about what a good actor he is while the music itself is really tense and clues you in that he's actually fucked and the police chief didn't actually give the order to pardon. He gets shot and dies with a look of shock on his face, and his girlfriend jumps off a cliff to avoid arrest, then curtains the end.

So in a meta sense, the two targets are actually playing the roles of the two opera characters, and 47 is actually playing the role of the executioner. Tosca is pretty babbys first opera tier so its not hard to see why it'd be one they'd be looking for level material in, but the way they pulled it off is actually really impressive.

Even without the spoon, he works ok with an Artemis bow.

To answer the thread question though, probably make sing similar to the spell command but have a list of songs, each song has verses with various effects, and the idea is that you spend several turns ramping them up for their benefits. For example, "Aria" starts by casting a weak cure on the the first verse (turn), and then if you continue it next turn it gives everyone protect, and then it loops between a medium cure, a strong cure, and a group revive if you continue. "Dirge" would debuff enemies with slow, poison, stop, and finally death.

I don't really like Edward being a powerful character though, I think it's central to his arc that he accepts he's not a warrior but has other ways to aid Cecil in his quest. A lot of the supporting cast is that way, Cid for example wields a mean hammer but is first and foremost an airship engineer, Tellah is an old man past his prime, and the twins are still just children even if they are prodigies. Yang is the only one that really could fill the role of a hero in the party in my opinion, being an actual warrior from Fabul.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
He's a prince, who has focused on the delicate art of music, from a kingdom that has a weird hovercraft... I could see him being developed into an Edgar Figaro kind of party member who uses gadgets in battle. But his tools would be ones he encountered during the journey and discovered he could adapt himself to (thanks to his princely education, artistic sensibility, and clever fingers), not ones he designed himself.

From the start, he could do stuff with his harp(s) like what others here are suggesting. Then maybe while the group is staying the night among the underworld dwarves or Eblan's ninjas, he chats with some locals and gains basic training in some other clever mechanical or magical tool that he could use well thanks to his unusual set of strengths. Like, I don't know, a programmable doll the dwarves have that can carry a bomb to an enemy, or a small set of unique spells (kinda like Edge's spells) that he learns from some old scroll you find somewhere that nobody else can read because it uses an outmoded writing style that only fruity royal types and dusty scholars like Tellah ever learn (and Tellah's gone then). Maybe at some point he discovers he has a bit of aptitude for a certain kind of battle strategy and so can arrange for the party to surprise enemies and get first strike more often, or even to disrupt enemies with a trick in the middle of a battle and give the party a round's worth of free turns right then. He could just build up various odd abilities here and there, gradually becoming more useful and gaining confidence.

Then during the endgame he finally achieves his final form when you go deep into a lunar cavern and discover a set of ancient mech suits that are driven via piano keyboards or something, and nobody can get them to do anything except musical Edward, so now he's a cyborg with a shoulder-mounted cannon and he's as sturdy as Cecil. And also the ghost of Anna occasionally aids him in battle and she's naked and looks really pretty.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9600491
How u know 2 is the peak without having played 1

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9600430
1 is a straight up isometric metal gear
your offensive choices only stun enemies, core gameplay is about stealthing around enemies over several dungeons, its old school linear (stage 1, stage 2, and so on) no rpg mechanics

Boktai 2 introduces stats(STR,ENG,AGI), level ups, a variety of offensive options, you can now defeat enemies or still stealth(backstabbing triples damage) and a decent sized connected world map with a hub in the middle, progression is linear like modern zelda games (must beat dungeon A before you can visit dungeon B) but you have a certain degree of freedom to roam, grind and craft itens

Boktai 3 ditches the connected world map
and goes back to stage selecting, bigger dungeons but outside dungeons you only interact with npcs through menus

>Also can I enjoy 2 without having played 1?
Yes, you get a recap at the start of the game

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9599736
Russian here. Especially today, Gorby is hated by many of people, but especially those who idolize USSR.
Technically, Gorby had good intentions of gradually turning USSR into more free-market and democratic country. But, he came at the worst time possible. Oil profits crashed after the end of theOPEC oil embargo of the early '80s, and USSR was worn down by cold war and its own internal conflicts ready to explode (see >>9599561). Everything was slowly going to shit very fast, and the country could no longer afford to import food with oil bucks.
Gorby decided to start gradual transition to free market. However, unlike China, which started implementing free market from the bottom (first farmers going private, then small businesses, then small factories, then large factories, and so on), he did it from the top. This only created a very dysfunctional system that achieved nothing and satisfied no one. The country was nearing a huge food crisis, the internal conflicts and unrests were happening one by one, but Gorby was mostly trying to promote free speech, democracy and stuff like that.
All this led to Yeltsin getting power and the collapse of the Soviet union. Plenty people lost their jobs overnight, the country entered into a huge inflation and economic downturn, while corruption reached insane levels and the country went into a lawless period called "the wild '90s", with organized crime getting out of control. To this day, Russia is burdened with the consequences of this, from plenty people who were left jobless because they depended on state economy, to politics, when all these new states around Russia turned very anti-Russian.
This is how Gorby got his image of either a weak bumbling idiot, or a corrupt bad guy who destroyed USSR. The only people who ever think positively about him are the libs, and even they realize he made a whole lot of fuck ups.

There wasn’t much to Metroid before Super-Metroid, and even then it was a dead franchise until Retro came along with the idea for Metroid-Prime to reinvent it. F-Zero also never was reinvented, just “zomg new graphics” a couple times and then graphics plateaued so they let it die, and Nintento took the mechanics for the canned F-Zero ZX to make Mario/Kart 8 instead. After Mario-Kart’s success, we’ll never get a new F-Zero.

Any franchise that doesn’t get reinvented from Nintento is doomed to die.

Frames of delay, giving the rollback netcode the leeway to work. More frames of delay means higher input lag (ovbiously) but a stabler experience (less teleports)
A combination of brute-forcing+coding magic results in Slippi having 2 less frames of input lag compared to console, so that means that playing with 2f is effectively the same delay as console+CRT (provided you have a good monitor)

>>9591461
I'm a Link main, and while it's true quite a bit of lag was lopped off his movements and some of his attacks in Brawl and afterward, he's still MUCH more fun to play in Melee regardless once you've gained a degree of mastery over his moveset. You can projectile spam to your heart's content, with a great deal of control over his projectiles (his bombs have great interaction potential, as does his boomerang). You can settle for a balance of projectile spam at long range with shffld aerials in the short range. Or you can even surprise your opponents and go on a full retard aggressive shffld aerial offensive with few to no projectiles (this last one is the weakest, but can catch opponents off-guard since not many would play Link this way). His edge and recovery game is also fun thanks to his wall tethers which give him tools to keep the opponent guessing as to your recovery path. Mind you, despite all this he still gets shit on by the top tiers, especially the space animals, but he's not as clunky as people think, and he's horribly simplified in later versions and IMO nowhere near as fun to dick around with.

>>9592695
Link and Y. Link's Hookshot and Samus's Grapple Beam. When used off-stage, unlike in Brawl and beyond, they can hang onto pretty much any wall at any point, and several cool things can be done with them. You can extend them up and down, and can be canceled with a button press at any point from the moment they make contact with the wall to when you're hanging down, at which point your character will quickly "jump" upwards. If you're skilled, this makes their recoveries more dynamic and can keep the opponent guessing as to your recovery path, and IIRC you can even attack out of cancelling. It's really fucking fun, and their removal in favor of a boring auto-snap onto the ledge was a travesty but in keeping with Sakurai's overall drive to casualize the shit out of Smash.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9596163
There was more volume back in the 90s, lots of people put out something simple of low substance which isn't particularly interesting, and together with the far less advanced and easy to use tools, as well as the original .exe's lack of flexibility, with the overall lack of understanding just how the game works (at least for the first couple of years), the era can come off as overall unrefined and slapdash.

That said, there were a lot of creative and ambitious types who put real effort into projects, and there's stuff from then worth checking out, be it Evilution, Plutonia, Memento Mori 1 & 2, Obituary, Aliens TC, etc.
People also did goofy shit for the fun of it, like numerous builds and takes on Simpson's Doom (one which I'm particularly fond of), or one of those South Park ones like in OP's pic. Things like those don't have much depth, but they are neat take a look at if you were around for any part of the era, if just for a quick chuckle.

>>9597721
Immoral Conduct was the absolute shit, though that's (mostly) early 2000s, the time period some would argue was the golden age for Doom maps, where you had stuff like Alien Vendetta. The 1997 source code release did so much to open up possibilities.

>>9597926
Why keep pushing this lie?

>激しいアクションでも不自然にならないように胸部を締める必要がありました" was translated into "we make sure her top wasn't loose so that her chest wouldn't come off as unnatural during heavy action sequences" though, the original Japanese clearly said "胸部を締める必要がありました" so the literal and authentic translation is "in order for it not to appear unnatural in heavy action sequences, we needed to tighten her chest" It's a big mystery why this translator perfectly omitted the part "胸部を締める必要がありました" and really euphemistically translated it.

>And, an another really dubious point is as for "指示" which was translated into "Our ethics department had asked". in Japanese, "指示" is really a strong word, unlike just "asking", that give a sense of "must" to listeners, so I will not translate "指示" to "ask" as in this translation, but translate it to "direction" which have a more strong implication of obligation. It is obvious that in the original Japanese they had no choice but to accept an offer from the ethic department.

Even more bizarre when even Japs themselves meme about the ethics committee. Clear cut and dry.

posts.com: There isn't a fool-proof HDMI solution to the PS2. The best options are Retrotink scalers. That's it. Component output is the easiest way to get the best native signal from a ps2, but 480i looks like dog shit. Retrotink just bob deinterlaces the signal, and that's only a marginal improvement. Emulation is, in my opinion, the best solution.

posts.com:
How the hell did the whole 3D platformer genre lose popularity so fast in 6th gen? 5th gen was all about SM64, Banjo, Crash, Spyro, and so on, and even so-so games like Croc managed to become pretty big. 6th gen started with Jak and Ratchet & Clank, but then the popularity of the genre went downhill hard. Crash got some traction at first, but then went downhill hard, Spyro seemingly lost any and all relevancy, and newer series seemingly never got any traction even if they were good (like Sly series). Past 2001, the genre seemingly went on a death spiral. Literally only Ratchet series survived this era.
I'm trying to think of reasons. I think 1) people simply had enough of the platformer mania of the 90s, 2) games moved in the "mature" direction, and the defining games of the era were no longer Sonic & Mario, but GTA3 and Halo. But both of these reasons seem pretty subjective. And how did Ratchet of all series survive it and last all the way till PS5?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9595170
3D platformers were just one of the best design spaces for what was available at the time. People were excited by exploring 3D worlds which have a lot more exploration possibility then 2D worlds. Platformers have a lot of vertical gameplay which lends itself to exploration. And with the limited graphical scale cartoony style had a lot of potential. Shooting (golden eye) and melee combat (ocarina) were decent at their very best and wonky most of the time.

The 5th generation was about creating interesting spectable using the new super-graphics but clunky controls. And the three approaches that dominated it were reflect this
*3D platformer: Fast real time movement that focused on being cute and colorful while exploring
*Survival horror: Slow real time movement that focused on realistic and dark. Less exploration but more tightly designed
*JRPG: Turn based or very slow real time that focused on epic adventure and game length.

posts.sub: Why does Wikipedia have the GBA SP AGS-101 screen listed as 50hz?
posts.com:
It's listed as 50hz on Wikipedia. When you check the source it's some random free literally who book that doesn't even say where it got that information from. I can't find a single other source that says the screen is 50hz. It doesn't even really make sense. For the screen to run at 50hz the games would have to run significantly slower or simply drop the extra frames resulting in stuttering. We can obviously see it's not doing either of these. So what's up with this? Remember, GB(C/A) games aren't like PC games. They're not designed to run at any framerate. Something's off here.

This is what they're using as a source BTW: https://books.google.com/books?id=J1aAAwAAQBAJ&q=nintendo+ds+refresh+rate&pg=PT799#v=snippet&q=nintendo ds refresh rate&f=false

This is the only place I can find this information...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9588762
Why come here with this stuff? Wikipedia is a collective effort and you're free to challenge anything mentioned provided you can reliably back it up. You mentioned on the talk page that "everything else" states it is 60Hz. This is very poor reasoning. If you can point the editors to one or multiple reliable sources stating to be 60Hz it will probably be changed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
While I don't think you should really worry about Wikipedia autism, here is when that specific line was added:
https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Game_Boy_Advance_SP&diff=prev&oldid=960237867
and here is the user that added it:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User:Maxeto0910

So he's from a pal region, but even so none of the GBAs ran in pal standards obviously...


The "AGS-101 runs at 50Hz" meme is really old, I remember seeing it like 10 years ago and I don't know where it comes from. But the frame rate in the GBA is determined by CPU cycles, not the display, and all of them run at 59.725ish hz except for the Game Boy Player which duplicates a frame every few seconds to run at 59.94Hz (which gives it it's awful stutter)

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9589534

So what you can do? First, use the talk page to list your doubts:
— Single low quality source.
— Source doesn't actually mention those model numbers.
— Direct TV output was not an option, no “PAL models” are known to exist. That said, it had nothing to do with NTSC either, the refresh rate was probably chosen to be similar enough to port existing games without recalculation of all timing constants.
— It would require a big technical mess to use a different refresh rate for the screen (another independent oscillator, wire speed buffering, and so on).
— Emulators have zero support for such a thing.

Then you simply edit the page to remove the statement about 50 Hz screen, and put “see talk page” in comment. Unless someone wants to defend the previous choice, YOU have writtene a better article for everyone.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Be_bold

>The Myth: The average person swallows eight spiders per year. Fear not. This "statistic" was not only made up out of whole cloth, it was invented as an example of the absurd things people will believe simply because they come across them on the Internet. In a 1993 PC Professional article, columnist Lisa Holst wrote about the ubiquitous lists of "facts" that were circulating via e-mail and how readily they were accepted as truthful by gullible recipients. To demonstrate her point, Holst offered her own made-up list of equally ridiculous "facts," among which was the statistic cited above about the average person's swallowing eight spiders per year, which she took from a collection of common misbeliefs printed in a 1954 book on insect folklore. In a delicious irony, Holst's propagation of this false "fact" has spurred it into becoming one of the most widely-circulated bits of misinformation to be found on the Internet.

it just means that the game would be more lenient with the players inputs. For example, picrel is some code from Kings Quest 3 that is for when the user types in "get mandrake powder". It allows for about 16 variations of that term and if the user types something else there'll be an error like "unknown command" or something
https://github.com/historicalsource/kings-quest-3/blob/main/SRC/RM10.CG#L625
But with a neural network you could probably give it half as many variations, like 8 or 10 or so, and it would allow for about 2x or 4x or more even possible user commands because of the way AI can make assumptions about inputs. So there would be less work for the developer and less "unknown command" messages for the user, so it would be a more modern experience

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
https://www.nintendolife.com/news/2016/12/feature_the_making_of_metal_gear_solid_the_twin_snakes

Meanwhile in Japan, there was a team of individuals at Konami - handpicked and overseen by Hideo Kojima - responsible for the key creative output. "Most of the actual decisions were made in Japan, including any new ideas to add/update, reviews, and approvals." Toledo reveals. "We at Silicon Knights generally did the grunt work, while the team in Japan did the meat of the assets. We generally modified their assets to enhance visual quality and clean up and optimize code." Traver adds an analogy to describe how the partnership worked. "Konami had made it very clear earlier on that we at Silicon Knights were creating the VCR to play their movie."

This new imagining of the visuals also extended to the cutscenes. Where characters previously had static faces and eyes made of pixels, on GameCube they had full animation and lip synching for dialogue - all of which was re-recorded with most of the original cast. In the position of director was Japanese filmmaker Ryuhei Kitamura, known for his high octane action films. As Kitamura explains, it was Hideo Kojima's love of films that landed him the job. "Hideo came and watched my first feature Versus and loved it and we became very good friends. When I was making Azumi he asked me if I'd be interested in doing cutscenes for Twin Snakes. How could I resist?!"

The in-game cutscenes weren't merely graphical updates either. They added new action set pieces, showcased great feats of strength from characters and emphasised elements like bullet-time. Although fans have debated this creative direction through the years, it was very much the wish of Kojima to explore new territory. "Hideo told me to go completely new and different." Kitamura reveals. "He gave me total freedom because he knew that I was a big fan of his work so that I would never do something he wouldn't want. He also loved my second movie Alive

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When it comes to Spider-Man video games from the early 2000's, it's most common to talk about the ones based on Sam Raimi's films, however there was something quite special just before that. Neversoft, at that point most well know for Tony Hawk's Pro Skater, took that engine and simply made what was, at least for its time, the best Spider-Man video game ever made... and they stopped there, focusing mostly on Tony Hawk from that point onwards. However, that wasn't the end of it for good, even though it was 2000, and Sam Raimi's 1st film came out in 2002, Activision made sure to release a lot more.

In that very same year we got a port on Nintendo's Game Boy Color, which was quite different, with areas being connected while Spider-Man leveled up to make progress in them more viable, a lite MetroidVania feel. In 2001 we got ports of Neversoft's original, though they were almost identical, besides making 100% completion a lot easier, since the Quick-Change suit, which used to require 10.000 points to unlock on the Zip-Line training, now required 7.500, still difficult, but much more possible. 2001 also gave us a sequel to Neversoft's original, this time by Vicarious Visions, called Enter Electro, only on PS1.

Activision wasn't satisfied with all of that, and got both Torus Games and Vicarious Visions, which was already working on Enter Electro, pump out a couple of portable titles, one for Game Boy Color and another on Game Boy Advance. Spider-Man 2: The Sinister Six was a sequel for the original Game Boy Color port of Neversoft's original, and it got rid of the more open style in favor of traditional levels. Mysterio's Menace is the one I wonder the most about though, it can be seen as a sort of Spider-Man 3... but is it a sequel to The Sinister Six or Enter Electro? It's portable, but everything it it looks like PS1 assets.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9595717
>In that very same year we got a port on Nintendo's Game Boy Color
OP here, I wrote this in the 1st post of the thread and realized that, out of the 5 installments in this series, if you can call it that, Spider-Man (2000/GBC) was the only one I still hadn't taken the time to play extensively and properly beat, so I decided to play it for a while today. I've decided that I'll beat it, just to complete this series whole, but I've got to say that to me this is the least enjoyable installment. I don't mind the idea of interconnected areas and a pseudo MetroidVania style, but the execution was not ideal at all, for quite a few reasons unfortunately:

1. All areas are nicely condensed and fun to explore except for a single one, the Sewers, which just happen to be where you'll spend most of your time by far, and with no map at all.
2. Flying enemies are the worst to fight against, as Spider-Man's not well equipped to deal with them, so they take a lot of health away, especially the bats... in the Sewers, of course.
3. Control isn't responsive, it takes a second for Spider-Man to respond, and not only that, he keeps too much momentum while on the ground, but his jumping barely goes forward.

I kept playing, giving up, picking it up again, then giving up... until I got sick of it and decided that either I went after a guide or I'd give up on this for good, so I swallowed my pride and used a guide. I feel that the experience is much better now, especially with a map of the Sewers, getting all of the hidden upgrades and taking the best routes so bats don't take away all of your health is ideal too, and almost kind of fun... but overall I can't help but feel that they dropped the ball on this one, both The Sinister Six and Mysterio's Menace were huge improvements.
>Spider-Man most dangerous enemies are bats and seagulls for some reason

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9596867
Well, just a little update, I've managed to beat it, though I'm not sure if it was a 100% run or not... I've found 2 guides, one from IGN back in the day, and another by Legomondo, I found both to be excellent, but regarding the Defense Upgrade, which are items you find in levels to upgrade your defense to a maximum of 6, there's something odd. Legomondo's guide mentions that Doc Ock's Lab has a Defense Upgrade, but you can level up both your attack and defense to 4 through XP, and then there are 2 Attack Upgrades you can find, which I did, but for defense it mentions a 3rd one in the last level, even though I had already found 2 by then and it doesn't make much sense to reach level 7 even though there isn't even a slot for it, I'm not sure if it's a mistake in the guide or not, but anyways I went into the last bosses completely leveled up in all fronts, so I suppose it counts as a 100% completion, though I'm not sure due to the guide.

Anyways, leaving my 100% completion OCD aside, I want to talk about this installment, a GBC port for one of my favorite video games of all time, which is the PS1 original by Neversoft, of course I didn't expect them to make something as good as that, but I was frustrated by my experience. I've mentioned how cryptic the Sewers are, and how you spend a lot of time lost there and getting swarmed by bats, flying enemies in general feel quite cheap. I still dislike how Spider-Man controls aswell, his jumping and momentum to be more specific, this should be one of the most agile characters in fiction, but he sure doesn't feel like that here. A lot of the concepts just aren't fleshed out enough, like how you pretty much have to grind for XP so you can fully level up Spider-Man... grinding, in a Spider-Man video game, doesn't feel right... also, if they wanted to make a MetroidVania, which I'm down for, they could've at least given players a map...

(1/2)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9597368
I know it all sounds quite negative so far, but it's not all bad though, far from it. One thing that I must stress though... if you're going to play this, do yourself a favor and use a guide, or else you'll probably want to quit as soon as you go to the Sewers for the 1st time, not knowing where to go because everything looks the same, getting attacked from all directions, with tons of bats swarming you and taking away all of your health as you try to find upgrades and fail because they're all hidden in the most cryptic manner possible... it takes a nosedive in quality here so a guide is a must, at least to me. Anyways, I was going to talk about what I liked... and there was lots of it, there's a reason I tried so hard to keep up when I could've just given up, there are lots of qualities here. Well, the 1st thing you'll notice is how it looks and sounds, not only are all sprites and environments well detailed for GBC standards, we've also got some quality tunes and SFX in the OST... and the best part to me is its atmosphere, it's dark, grim, but not edgy and overdone, it feels appropriate for the story told, which is also a good time really.

We have a password system that works well, as intended, and has an atmospheric and moody password screen too which I love... and while I think they messed up a lot of what they went for with this MetroidVania lite style, mostly in execution, some of it does work, when you know how to get all of the upgrades and power Spider-Man up, also some grinding to fully level him up, you feel the difference from early on, how you take enemies down quicker and with ease, when they used to give you trouble. Overall, it can be fun with a guide, combat is satisfying, at least apart from enemies constantly respawning, some level design is good, and atmosphere is perfect... but it can be a frustrating experience, especially for the reasons mentioned earlier here, still, I don't regret my time with it, and I'm glad I played it.

(2/2)

Absolutely adore this one. I've completed this, on all difficulty settings because I liked it so much, before the original, and now that I've played them close to one another I have to say that its improved so much on the foundation set by its predecessor. Of course it can be disappointing that they removed every MetroidVania element and went with a simple level to level structure, with a Spider-Man that doesn't change from start to finish... but this Spider-Man controls so much better that it's hard to care, especially his jumping, control is lovely here. Also, instead of having some levels you just want to skip through, like the city, subway and docks, and then levels that are ridiculously cryptic, like the sewers and lab, all levels here are well designed, not too linear, but also not too confusing to navigate, and you have a Spider-Sense that activates when you keep Spider-Man standing still, that points to your objective so you know where to go. I don't think the atmosphere, story, OST and graphics are as appealing as the original... but everything else is an improvement.

>>9599642
I'd say that both sequels improved on the foundation set by Vicarious Visions' original installment, Torus Games went in a completely different direction for the sequel, no upgrades and it has standard levels, which are well designed and fun to explore, while Vicarious Visions' returned for the next installment and polished concepts from their 1st attempt, allowing you to choose the order in which to play levels, again you find items to upgrade Spider-Man, but level design is more compact and enjoyable to play and explore, also both of them have difficulty settings. Don't feel bad about struggling, you shouldn't be too hard on yourself, even a developer apologized in that comment, it's because there were many problems with the video game, not with you, and speaking as someone who completed it for the 1st time recently, I don't see how it could be an enjoyable experience without a guide. If you'd like to give it another shot where you manage to get all upgrades, I'd recommend IGN's guide (https://web.archive.org/web/20090812055445/http://guidesarchive.ign.com/guides/14631/basics.html) due to it having a map for the sewers, and Legomondo's one as a complement (https://gamefaqs.gamespot.com/gbc/370571-spider-man/faqs/16982) as they were the guides that helped me out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's absolutely worth playing but I can't say whether or not you'll like it

It's a procedural dynamic game, it's not really about the story, it's not really about running around and finding stuff to do since you'll be fast travelling everywhere, both Arena and Daggerfall are closer to the fun of a game like Sid Meier's Pirates or even Mount and Blade than something like Skyrim

The idea is that you can make a character and roleplay, or you can sort of get caught up in the minutia of going around doing things and slowly building your character, go into town, try to find work, get some, fast travel, do some dungeon crawling (make sure to take recall as a spell) and return, last time I played I just ran around town trying to lockpick doors in the dead of night, I was losing my mind with how fun it was, but that's sort of it, it's a Dwarf Fortress "enjoy the dynamic gameplay" kind of thing

posts.com: How did the C64 manage to become the best selling computer ever? The disk drive was slower than on the Apple II which came out 5 years prior, and it was also really expensive because it had to contain it's own processor and RAM since the computer itself couldn't handle it, so a bunch of people kept sitting around with shitty tape readers instead.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9595552
The graphics and sound hardware, and low price for the base unit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9595552
>The disk drive was slower than on the Apple II which came out 5 years prior
By 1984 there were various fastloaders you could choose from, effectively making it even faster than the Apple II floppy depending on which fastloader you're getting.
>it was also really expensive because it had to contain it's own processor and RAM since the computer itself couldn't handle it
It was thanks to the dumb decision by the Commodore people to make it backwards compatible with the Commodore PET. On the bright side, having its own CPU and RAM meant it could easily be hacked to load the disks faster.
>so a bunch of people kept sitting around with shitty tape readers instead
The tape readers were fine. They're slow but very reliable relative to the tape decks on the other computers back in the day. Also, it was bearable with a fastloader, reducing the load time by 50%-80%, although with less reliable error checking. It wasn't necessarily a huge problem, pirated games for the tape often contained cheats and trainers, so if you die you wouldn't have to reload the tape from the beginning.
